DIV1.P: THE ENGLISH TRAVELLER. AS IT HATH BEENE Publikely acted at the COCK-PIT In Drury-lane: By Her Maiesties seruants.
LONDON, Printed by Robert Raworth: dwelling in Old Fish-street, neere Saint Mary Maudlins Church. 1633.

LIST.ITEM: Roger the Clowne Seruant to Olde Wincott.
Olde Lionell A Merchant father to yong Lionell.
Olde Mr. Geraldine Father to yong Geraldine.
The Owner of the house, supposed to be possest.

DIV1.HEAD: TO THE RIGHT WORSHIPFVLL Sir HENRY APPLETON, Knight Barronet, &c.
DIV1.P: FOr many reason I am induced, to present this Poem, to your fauourable acceptance; and not the least of them that alternate Loue, and those frequent curtesies which interchang∣ably past, betwixt your selfe and that good old Gentleman, mine vnkle (Master Edmund Heywood) whom you pleased to grace by the Title of Father: I must con∣fesse, I had altogether slept (my weaklines and bashfullnesse discouraging mee) had they not bin waken'd and animated, by that worthy Gentleman your friend, and my countrey∣man, Sir William Eluish, whom (for his vnmerited loue many wayes extended towards me,) I much honour; Nei∣ther Sir, neede you to thinke it any vnderualuing of your worth, to vndertake the patronage of a Poem in this nature, since the like hath beene done by Roman Laelius, Scipio, Mecaenas, and many other mighty Princes and Captaines, Nay, euen by Augustus Caesar himselfe, concerning whom Ouid is thus read, Detristi: lib. 2.
DIV1.L: Inspice ludorum sumptus Auguste tuorum
Empta tibimagno, talia multa leges.
Haec tu spectasti, spectandaque saepe de desti
Maiestas adeo comis vbique tua est.
DIV1.P: So highly were they respected in the most flourishing estate of the Roman Empire; and if they haue beene vilefied of late by any Separisticall humorist, (as in the now questio∣ned Histrio-mastix) I hope by the next Terme, (Minerua assistente) to giue such satisfaction to the world, by vindi∣cating many particulars in that worke maliciously exploded and condemned, as that no Gentleman of qualitie and iudge∣ment, but shall therein receiue a reasonable satisfaction; I am loth by tediousnesse to grow troublesome, therefore conclude with a gratefull remembrance of my seruice inter∣mixt with Miriads of zealous wishes for your health of bo∣dy, and peace of minde, with superabundance of Earths blessings, and Heauens graces, euer remaining;

DIV1.HEAD: To the Reader.
DIV1.P: IF Reader thou hast of this Play beene an audi∣tour? there is lesse apology to be vsed by intrea∣ting thy patience. This Tragi-Comedy (being one reserued amongst two hundred and twenty, in which I haue had either an entire hand, or at the least a maine finger, comming accidentally to the Presse, and I hauing Intelligence thereof, thought it not fit that it should passe as filius populi, a Bastard without a Father to ac∣knowledge it: True it is, that my Playes are not exposed unto the world in Volumes, to beare the title of Workes, (as others) one reason is, That many of them by shifting and change of Com∣panies, haue beene negligently lost, Others of them are still retained in the hands of some Actors, who thinke it against their peculiar profit to haue them come in Print, and a third, That it never was any great ambition in me, to bee in this kind Volumniously read. All that I haue further to say at this time is onely this: Censure I intreat as fauourably, as it is exposed to thy view freely. euer
DIV1.SIGNED: Studious of thy Pleasure and Profit, Thomas Heywood.

DIV1.HEAD: The Prologue.
DIV1.L: A Strange Play you are like to haue, for know,
We use no Drum, nor Trumpet, nor Dumbe show;
No Combate, Marriage, not so much to day,
As Song, Dance, Masque, to bumbaste out a Play;
Yet thèse all good, and still in frequent vse
With our best Poets; nor is this excuse
Made by our Author, as if want of skill
Caus'd this defect; it's rather his selfe will:
Will you the reason know? There haue so many
Beene in that kind, that Hee desires not any
At this time in His Sceane, no helpe, no straine,
Or flash that's borrowed from an others braine;
Nor speakes Hee this that Hee would haue you feare it,
He onely tries if once bare Lines will beare it;
Yet may't afford, so please you silent sit,
Some Mirth, some Matter, and perhaps some Wit.

DIV3.HEAD: Scena prima.
DIV3.STAGE: Enter young Geraldine and master Dalauill.

SP.SPEAKER: Dal.
SP.L: OH friend, that I to mine owne Notion
Had ioyned but your experience; I haue the
Theoricke, But you the Practicke.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Ger.
SP.L: I perhaps, haue seene what you haue onely read of.

SP.SPEAKER: Dal.
SP.L: There's your happinesse.
A Scholler in his study knowes the starres,
Their motion and their influence, which are fixt,
And which are wandering, can decipher Seas,
And giue each seuerall Land his proper bounds;
But set him to the Compasse, hee's to secke,
When a plaine Pilot can, direct his course
From hence vnto both th'Indies; can bring backe
His ship and charge, with profits quintuple.
I haue read Ierusalem, and studied Rome,
Can tell in what degree each City stands,
Describe the distance of this place from that,
All this the Scale in euery Map can teach,
Nay, for a neede could punctually recite
The Monuments in either; but what I
Haue by relation onely, knowledge by trauell
Which still makes vp a compleat Gentleman,
Prooues eminent in you.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Ger.
SP.L: I must confesse,
I haue seene Ierusalem and Rome, haue brought
Marke from th'one, from th'other Testimony,
Know Spaine, and France, and from their ayres haue snckt
A breath of euery language: but no more
Of this discourse since wee draw neere the place
Of them we goe to visit.

SP.SPEAKER: Clo.
SP.L: Noble master Geraldine, worshipfull master Dalauill.

SP.SPEAKER: Dal.
SP.L: I see thou still remember'st vs.

SP.SPEAKER: Clo.
SP.P: Remember you, I haue had so many memorandomes from the multiplicities of your bounties, that not to remember you were to forget my selfe, you are both most ingeniously and nobly welcome.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Ger.
SP.P: And why ingeniously and nobly?

SP.SPEAKER: Clo.
SP.P: Because had I giuen your welcomes other attributes then I haue done, the one being a Souldier, and the other seeming a Scholler, I should haue lied in the first, and shewed my selfe a kind of block∣head in the last.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Ger.
SP.L: I see your wit is nimble as your tongue,
But how doth all at home?

SP.SPEAKER: Clo.
SP.P: Small doings at home sir, in regard that the age of my Master corresponds not with the youth of my Mistris, and you know cold Ianuary and lusty May seldome meet in coniunction.

SP.SPEAKER: Dal.
SP.P: I doe not thinke but this fellow in time may for his wit and vnderstanding make Almanackes?

SP.SPEAKER: Clo.
SP.P: Not so sir, you being more iudicious then I, ile giue you the preeminence in that, because I see by proofe you haue such iudgement in times and seasons.

SP.SPEAKER: Dal.
SP.P: And why in times and seasons?

SP.SPEAKER: Clo.
SP.P: Because you haue so seasonably made choise, to come so iust at dinner time; you are welcome Gentlemen, ile goe tell my Master of your comming.

SP.SPEAKER: Dal.
SP.L: A pleasant knaue.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Ger.
SP.L: This fellow I perceiue
Is well acquainted with his Masters mind,
Oh tis a good old man.

SP.SPEAKER: Dal.
SP.L: And shee a Lady.
For Beauty and for Vertue vnparraleld,
Nor can you name that thing to grace a woman
Shee has not in a full perfection,
Though in their yeeres might seeme disparity.
And therefore at the first, a match vnsit;
Imagine but his age and gouernement,
Withall, her modesty, and chaste respect;
Betwixt them, there's so sweet a simpathie,
As crownes a noble marriage.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Ger.
SP.L: Tis acknowledged,
But to the worthy gentleman himselfe,
I am so bound in many courtesies,
That not the least, by all th' expression
My Labour, or my Industry can shew,
I will know how to cancell.

SP.SPEAKER: Dal.
SP.L: Oh you are modest.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Ger.
SP.L: Hee studies to engrosse mee to himself,
And is so wedded to my company,
Hee makes mee stranger to my Fathers house,
Although so neere a neighbour.

SP.SPEAKER: Dal.
SP.L: This approues you,
To be most nobly propertied, that from one
So exquisite in Iudgement, can Attract
So affectionate an eye.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Ger.
SP.L: Your Carracter,
I must bestow on his vnmerrited Ioue,
As one that know I haue it, and yet ignorant
Which way I should deserue it: Heere both come.

DIV3.STAGE: Enter old Mr. Wincott, Wife, Prudentilla the sister, and the Clowne.

SP.SPEAKER: Winc.
SP.L: Gentlemen, welcome, but what neede I vse
A word so common, vnto such to whom
My house was neuer priuate; I expect
You should not looke for such a needles phrase,
Especially you Master Geraldine,
Your Father is my neighbour, and I know you,
Euen from the Cradle, then I loued your Infancy,
And since your riper growth better'd by trauell;
My wife and you, in youth were play-fellowes,
And nor now be strangers; as I take it,
Not aboue two yeeres different in your Age.

SP.SPEAKER: Wife.
SP.L: So much hee hath out stript mee.

SP.SPEAKER: Winc.
SP.L: I would haue you
Thinke this your home, free as your Fathers house,
And to command it, as the Master on 't;
Call bouldly heere, and entertaine your friends,
As in your owne possessions, when I see't,
Ile say you loue me truely, not till then;
Oh what a happinesse your Father hath,
Farre aboue mee, one to inherit after him,
Where I (Heauen knowes) am childlesse.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Ger.
SP.L: That defect
Heauen hath supplied in this your vertuous Wife,
Both faire, and full of all accomplishments.
My Father is a Widower, and heerein
Your happinesse transcends him.

SP.SPEAKER: Wife.
SP.L: Oh Master Geraldine,
Flattery in Men's an adiunct of their sex,
This Countrie breeds it, and for that, so farre
You needed not to haue trauell'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Ger.
SP.L: Trueth's a word,
That should in euery language relish well,
Nor haue I that exceeded.

SP.SPEAKER: Wife.
SP.L: Sir, my Husband
Hath tooke much pleasure in your strange discourse
About Ierusalem and the Holy Land;
How the new Citie differs from the old,
What ruines of the Temple yet remayne,
And whether Sion, and those hills about,
With these Adiacent Townes and Villages,
Keepe that proportioned distance as wee read;
And then in Rome, of that great Piramis
Reared in the Front, on foure Lyons Mounted,
How many of those Idoll Temples stand,
First dedicated to their Heathen gods,
Which ruined, which to better vse repayred,
Of their Panthaeon, and their Capitoll,
What Structures are demolish't, what remaine.

SP.SPEAKER: Winc.
SP.L: And what more pleasure to an old mans eare,
That neuer drew, saue his owne Countries aire,
Then heare such things related. I doe exceed him
In yeeres, I must confesse, Yet he much older
Then I in his experience.

SP.SPEAKER: Prud.
SP.L: Master Geraldine,
May I bee bould to aske you but one question.
The which I'de be resolued in.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Ger.
SP.L: Any thing, that lies within my knowledge.

SP.SPEAKER: Winc.
SP.L: Put him too't,
Doe Sister, you shall finde him (make no doubt)
Most pregnant in his answere.

SP.SPEAKER: Prud.
SP.L: In your trauells
Through France, through Sauoye, and through Italy,
Spaine, and the Empire, Greece and Palestine,
Which breedes the choycest beauties.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Ger.
SP.L: Introath Lady
I neuer cast on any in those parts
A curious eye of censure, since my Trauell
Was onely aymed at Language, and to know;
These past me but as common objects did,
Seene, but not much regarded.

SP.SPEAKER: Prud.
SP.L: Oh you striue
To expresse a most vnheard of modestie,
And seldome found in any Traueller,
Especially of our Courtrey, thereby seeking
To make your selfe peculiar.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Ger.
SP.L: I should be loath
Professe in outward shew to be one Man,
And prooue my selfe another.

SP.SPEAKER: Prud.
SP.L: One thing more,
Were you to marry, You that know these clymes,
Their states and their conditions, out of which
Of all these countries would you chuse your wife.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Ger.
SP.L: Ile answere you in briefe, (as I obserue)
Each seuerall clime for obiect, fare, or vse,
Affords within it selfe, for all of these
What is most pleasing to the man there borne;
Spaine, that yeelds scant of food, affords the Nation
A parsimonious stomach, where our appetites
Are not content but with the large excesse
Of a full table; where the pleasing'st fruits
Are found most frequent, there they best content;
Where plenty flowes, it askes abundant Feasts;
For so hath proudent Nature dealt with all;
So in the choyce of Women, the Greeke wantons
Comple'd beneath the Turkish slauery,
Vassaile themselues to all men, and such best
Please the voluptious, that delight in change;
The French is of one humor, Spaine another,
The hot Italian hee's a straine from both,
All pleased with their owne nations euen the Moore,
Hee thinks the blackest the most beautifull;
And Lady, since you so farre taxe my choyce,
Ile thus resolue you; Being an English man,
Mong'st all these Nations I haue seene or tri'd,
To please me best, heere would I chuse my bride.

SP.SPEAKER: Pru.
SP.L: And happy were that Lady, in my thoughts,
Whom you id deine that grace too.

SP.SPEAKER: Wife.
SP.L: How now Sister,
This is a fashion that's but late come vp,
For maids to court their husbands.

SP.SPEAKER: Winc.
SP.L: I would wife
It were no worse, vpon condition,
They had my helping hand and purse to boote,
With both in ample measure; oh this Gentleman,
I loue, nay almost doate on.

SP.SPEAKER: Wife.
SP.L: Ya'ue my leaue,
To giue it full expression.

SP.SPEAKER: Winc.
SP.L: In these armes then,
Oh had my youth bin blest with such a sonne,
To haue made my estate to my name hereditary,
I should haue gone contented to my graue,
As to my bed; to death, as to my sleepe;
But Heauen hath will in all things, once more welcome,
And you sir, for your friends sake.

SP.SPEAKER: Dal.
SP.L: Would I had in mee,
That which he hath, to haue clamd it for mine owne,
How euer, I much thanke you.

SP.SPEAKER: Winc.
SP.L: Now sir, the newes with you.

SP.SPEAKER: Clo.
SP.L: Dancing newes sir,
For the meat stands piping hot vpon the dresser,
The kitchin's in a heat and the Cooke hath so bestir'd himselfe,
That hee's in a sweat. The Iacke plaies Musicke, and the Spits
Turne round too't.

SP.SPEAKER: Winc.
SP.L: This fellowes my best clocke,
Hee still strikes trew to dinner.

SP.SPEAKER: Clo.
SP.P: And to supper too sir, I know not how the day goes with you, but my stomacke hath strucke twelue, I can assure you that.

SP.SPEAKER: Winc.
SP.L: You take vs vnprouided Gentlemen,
Yet something you shall finde and wee would rather
Giue you the entertaine of houshold guests,
Then complement of strangers, I pray enter.

SP.SPEAKER: Clo.
SP.P: Ile stand too't, that in good hospitality, there can be nothing found that's ill, he that's a good house-keeper, keepes a good table, a good table, is neuer without good stooles, good stooles, seldome without good guests, good guests, neuer without good cheere, good cheere, cannot bee without good stomackes, good sfomackes, without good digestion, good digestion, keepes men in good health, and there∣fore all good people, that beare good minds, as you loue goodnesse, be sure to keepe good meat and drinke in your houses, and so you shall be called good men, and nothing can come on't but good, I warrant you.

DIV3.HEAD: Actus Primus. Scena Secundus.
DIV3.STAGE: Enter two seruing-men Reignald and Robin.

SP.SPEAKER: Reig.
SP.L: Away you Corridon.

SP.SPEAKER: Rob.
SP.L: Shall I bee beate out of my Masters houe thus?

SP.SPEAKER: Reig.
SP.L: Thy Master, wee are Lords amongst our selues,
And heere we Liue and Reigne, Two yeeres already
Are past of our great Empire, and wee now
Write, Anno Tertio.

SP.SPEAKER: Rob.
SP.L: But the old man lives,
That shortly will depose you.

SP.SPEAKER: Reig.
SP.L: Ith' meane time,
I, as the mighty Lord and Seneshcall
Of this great house and castle, banish thee,
The very smell ath' kitchin, bee it death,
To appeare before the dresser,

SP.SPEAKER: Rob.
SP.L: And why so?

SP.SPEAKER: Reig.
SP.L: Because thou stink'st of garlike, is that breath
Agreeing with our Pallace, where each Roome,
Smells with Muske, Ciuit, and rich Amber-greece,
Alloes, Cassia, Aromaticke-gummes,
Perfumes, and Pouders, one whose very garments
Scent of the fowlds and stables, oh fie, fie,
What a base nastie rogue tis.

SP.SPEAKER: Rob.
SP.L: Yet your fellow.

SP.SPEAKER: Reig.
SP.L: Then let vs put a Cart-Horse in rich trappings.
And bring him to the Tilt-yard.

SP.SPEAKER: Rob.
SP.L: Prancke it, doe,
Waste, Ryot, and Consume, Mispend your Howres
In drunken Surfets, lose your dayes in sleepe,
And burne the nights in Reuells, Drinke and Drab,
Keepe Christmasse all yeere long, and blot leane Lent
Out of the Calender; all that masse of wealth
Got by my Masters sweat and thristy care,
Hauocke in prodigall vses; Make all flie,
Powr't downe your oylie throats, or send it smoaking
Out at the tops of chimnies: At his departure,
Was it the old mans charge to haue his windowes
Glister all night with Starres? his modest House
Turn'd to a common Stewes? his Beds to pallats
Of Lusts and Prostitutions? his Buttrey hatch
Now made more common then a Tauernes barre,
His Stooles that welcom'd none but ciuill guests,
Now onely free for Pandars, Whores and Bawdes,
Strumpets, and such.

SP.SPEAKER: Reig.
SP.L: I suffer thee too long,
What is to me thy countrey, or to thee
The pleasure of our Citie? thou hast Cowes,
Cattell, and Beeues to feed, Oues and Boues,
These that I keepe, and in this pasture graze,
Are dainty Damosellaes, bonny Girles;
If thou be'st borne to Hedge, Ditch, Thrash and Plough
And I to Reuell, Banquet and Carrowe;
Thou Pessant, to the Spade and Pickaxe, I
The Battoone and Steeletto thinke it onely
Thy ill, my good, our seuerall lots are cast,
And both must be contented.

SP.SPEAKER: Rob.
SP.L: But when both our seruices are questioned.

SP.SPEAKER: Reig.
SP.L: Looke thou to one,
My answere is prouided.

SP.SPEAKER: Rob.
SP.L: Farewell Musk-Cat.

SP.SPEAKER: Reig.
SP.L: Adue good Cheese and Oynons, stuffe thy guts
With Specke and Barley-pudding for disgestion,
Drinke Whig and sowre Milke, whilest I rince my Throat,
With Burdeaux and Caarie.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Lio.
SP.L: What was hee?

SP.SPEAKER: Reig.
SP.L: A Spie Sir,
One of their Hindes oth' countrey, that came prying
To see what dainty fare our kitchin yeelds,
What Guests we harbour, and what rule we keepe,
And threats to tell the old man when he comes;
I thinke I sent him packing.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Lio.
SP.L: It was well done.

SP.SPEAKER: Reig.
SP.L: A whoreson-Iack-an-apes, a base Baboone,
To insinuate in our secrets.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Lio.
SP.L: Let such keepe, the Countrey where their charge is.

SP.SPEAKER: Reig.
SP.L: So I said Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Lio.
SP.L: And visit vs when we command them thence,
Not search into our counsels.

SP.SPEAKER: Reig.
SP.L: 'Twere not fit.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Lio.
SP.L: Who in my fathers absence should command,
Saue I his only sonne?

SP.SPEAKER: Reig.
SP.L: It is but iustice.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Lio.
SP.L: For am not I now Lord?

SP.SPEAKER: Reig.
SP.L: Dominus fac totum.
And am not I your Steward?

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Lio.
SP.L: Well remembred,
This night I haue a purpose to bee Merry,
Iouiall and Frollicke, how doth our cash hold out?

SP.SPEAKER: Reig.
SP.L: The bag's still heauy.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Lio.
SP.L: Then my heart's still light.

SP.SPEAKER: Reig.
SP.L: I can assure you, yet tis pritty deepe,
Tho scarce a mile to th' bottome.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Lio.
SP.L: Let mee haue
to Supper, Let mee see, a Ducke—

SP.SPEAKER: Reig.
SP.L: Sweet Rogue.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Lio.
SP.L: A Capon—

SP.SPEAKER: Reig.
SP.L: Geld the Rascall.

SP.SPEAKER: Y Lio.
SP.L: Then a Turkey—

SP.SPEAKER: Reig.
SP.L: Now spit him for an Infidell.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Lio.
SP.L: Greene Plouer, Snite,
Partridge, Larke, Cocke, and Phessant.

SP.SPEAKER: Reig.
SP.L: Nere a Widgin?

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Lio.
SP.L: Yes, wait thy selfe at Table.

SP.SPEAKER: Reig.
SP.L: Where I hope your selfe will not be absent.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Lio.
SP.L: Nor my friends.

SP.SPEAKER: Reig.
SP.L: Weele haue them then in plenty.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Lio.
SP.L: Cauiare, Sturgeon, Anchoues, pickle Oysters: Yes,
And a Potato Pie; besides all these,
What thou think'st rare and costly.

SP.SPEAKER: Reig.
SP.L: Sir, I know
What's to be done; the stocke that must be spent,
Is in my hands, and what I haue to doe,
I will doe suddenly.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Lio.
SP.L: No Butchers meat,
Of that, beware in any case.

SP.SPEAKER: Reig.
SP.L: I still remember,
Your father was no Grasier, if he were,
This were a way to eate vp all his Fields,
Hedges and all.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Lio.
SP.L: You will be gone sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Reig.
SP.L: Yes, and you are ith' way going.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Lio.
SP.L: To what may yong men best compare themselues?
Better to what, then to a house new built?
The Fabricke strong, the Chambers well contriu'd,
Polisht within, without, well beautifi'd;
When all that gaze vpon the Edifice,
Doe not alone commend the workemans craft,
But either make it their faire president
By which to build another, or at least,
Wish there to inhabite: Being set to sale,
In comes a slothfull Tenant, with a Family
As lasie and debosht; Rough tempests rise,
Vntile the roofe, which by their idlenesse,
Left vnrepaired, the stormy showres beat in,
Rot the maine Postes and Rafters, spoile the Roomes,
Deface the Seelings, and in little space,
Bring it to vtter Ruine, yet the fault,
Not in the Architector that first reared it,
But him that should repaire it: So it fares
With vs yong men; Wee are those houses made,
Our Parents raise these Structures, the foundation
Laid in our Infancy; and as wee grow
In yeeres, they striue to build vs by degrees,
Story on story higher; vp at height,
They couer vs with Councell, to defend vs
From stormes without: they polish vs within,
With Learnings, Knowledge, Arts and Diseiplines;
All that is nought and vicious, they sweepe from vs,
Like Dust and Cobwebs, and our Roomes concealed,
Hang with the costliest hangings; Bout the Walls,
Emblemes and beautious Symbols pictured round;
But when that lasie Tenant, Loue, steps in,
And in his Traine, brings Sloth and Negligence,
Lust, Disobedience, and profuse Excesse;
The Thrist with which our fathers tiled our Roofes,
Submits to euery storme and Winters blast,
SP.STAGE: Enter Blanda a Whore, and Scapha a Bawde.
SP.L: And yeelding place to euery riotous sinne,
Giues way without, to ruine what's within:
Such is the state I stand in.

SP.SPEAKER: Blan.
SP.L: And how doth this Tire become me?

SP.SPEAKER: Sca.
SP.L: Rather aske, how your sweet carriage,
And Court behauiour, doth best grace you, for Loucrs regard,
Not so much the outward habit, as that which the garment couers.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Lio.
SP.L: Oh heer's that Haile, Shower, Tempest, Storme, and Gust,
That shatter'd hath this building; Let in Lust,
Intemperance appetite to Vice; withall,
Neglect of euery Goodnesse; Thus I see,
How I am sincking in mine owne disease,
Yet can I not abide it.

SP.SPEAKER: Bla.
SP.L: And how this Gowne? I prethee view mee well,
And speake with thy best Iudgement.

SP.SPEAKER: Sca.
SP.L: What doe you talke of Gownes, and Ornaments;
That haue a Beautie, pretious in it selfe,
And becomes any thing.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Lio.
SP.L: Let me not liue, but she speaks nought but truth,
And ile for that reward her.

SP.SPEAKER: Bla.
SP.L: All's one to mee, become they mee, or not,
Or bee I faire, or fowle, in others eyes,
So I appeare so to my Lionell,
Hee is the glasse, in whom I iudge my face,
By whom in order, I will dresse these curles,
And place these Iewels, onely to please him,
Why do'st smile.

SP.SPEAKER: Sca.
SP.P: To heere a Woman, that thinks her selfe so wise, speake so foolishlie, that knowes well, and does ill.

SP.SPEAKER: Bla.
SP.P: Teach me wherein I erre.

SP.SPEAKER: Sca.
SP.P: Ile tell thee Daughter; In that thou knowest thy selfe to bee beloued of so many, and setlest thy affection, only vpon one; Doth the Mill grinde onely, when the Wind sits in one corner? Or Shippsonely Saile, when it's in this, or that quarter? Is hee a cunning Fencer, that lies but at one Guard? Or he a Skilfull Musician, that plaies but on one String? Is there but one way to the Wood? And but one Bucket that belongs to the Well? To affect one, and despise all other, becomes the precise Matron, not the Prostitute; the loyall Wife, not the loose Wanton: Such haue I beene, as you are now, and should learne, to Saile with all Windes, defend all Blowes, make Musicke with all Strings, know all the wayes, to the Wood, and like a good trauelling Hackney, learne to drinke of all Waters.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Lio.
SP.L: May I miscarry in my Blandaes loue;
If I that old damnation, doe not send
To Hell, before her time.

SP.SPEAKER: Bla.
SP.L: I would not haue you Mother, teach me ought,
That tends to iniure him.

SP.SPEAKER: Sca.
SP.P: Well looke too't when 'tis late, and then repent at leasure, as I haue done; Thou see'st, heeres nothing but Prodigallity and Pride, Wantoning, and Wasting, Rioting, and Reuelling, Spoyling, and Spending, Gluttony, and Gormondising, all goes to Hauocke, and can this hold out? When he hath nothing left, to helpe himselfe, how can he Harbour thee? Looke at length, to Drinke from a dry Bottle, and feed from an emptie Knap-sacke, looke too 't, 'twill come to that.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Lio.
SP.L: My parsemony shall begin in thee,
And instantly, for from this houre, I vow,
That thou no more shalt Drinke vpon my cost,
Nor taste the smallest Fragment from my Board;
Ile see thee starue ith' street first.

SP.SPEAKER: Sca.
SP.P: Liue to one man? a ieast, thou may'st aswell, tie thy selfe to one Gowne; and what Foole, but will change with the Fashion, Yes, doe, Confine thy selfe to one Garment, and vse no Varietie, and see how foone it will Rot, and turne to Raggs.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Lio.
SP.L: Those Raggs, be thy Reward; Oh my sweet Blanda,
Onely for Thee, I wish my Father dead,
And neere to Rouse vs from our Sweet delight;
But for this Hag, this Beldam, shee whose backe,
Hath made her Items, in my Mercers Bookes,
Whose raucnous Guts, I haue Stuft with Delicates,
Nay euen to Surfit; And whose frozen Blood,
I haue Warmed with Aquauitae; Be this day
My last of Bounty, to a Wretch Ingrate,
But vnto Thee, a new Indenture Scaled,
Of an affection fixt, and Permanent,
Ile loue thee still, bee 't but to giue the lye,
To this old Cancker'd Worme.

SP.SPEAKER: Bla.
SP.L: Nay, be not angrie.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Lio.
SP.L: With thee, my Soule shall euer be at peace,
But with this loue seducer, still at Warre.

SP.SPEAKER: Sca.
SP.L: Heere me but speake.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Lio.
SP.L: Ope but thy lips againe, it makes a way,
To haue thy Tongue pluck'd out.

SP.SPEAKER: Rio.
SP.L: What all in Tempest?

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Lio.
SP.L: Yes, and the Storme, raised by that Witches Spells.
Oh 'tis a Damn'd Inchantresse.

SP.SPEAKER: Rio.
SP.L: What's the businesse?

SP.SPEAKER: Bla.
SP.L: Onely some few words, slipt her vnawares,
For my Sake, make her peace.

SP.SPEAKER: Rio.
SP.L: You charge me deepely,
Come Friend, will you be Moou'd at womens Words,
A man of your knowne iudgement?

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Lio.
SP.L: Had you but heard,
The damn'd Erronious Doctrine that shee taught,
You would haue iudg'd her to the Stake.

SP.SPEAKER: Bla.
SP.L: But Sweet heart,
Shee now Recants those Errours, once more Number her
Amongst your Houshold seruants.

SP.SPEAKER: Rio.
SP.L: Shall she beg, and be denyed ought from you?

SP.SPEAKER: Bla.
SP.L: Come this Kisse, Shall end all former quarells.

SP.SPEAKER: Rio.
SP.L: 'Tis not possible,
Those Lippes should mooue in vaine, that two wayes plead;
Both in their Speech, and Silence.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Lio.
SP.L: You haue preuail'd,
But vpon this Condition, no way else,
Ile Sensure her, as shee hath Sentenc'd thee;
But with some small Inuersion,

SP.SPEAKER: Rio.
SP.L: Speake, how's that?

SP.SPEAKER: Bla.
SP.L: Not too seuere, I prethee see poore wretch,
Shee at the barre, stands quaking.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Lio.
SP.L: Now, hold vp?

SP.SPEAKER: Rio.
SP.L: How man, how?

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Lio.
SP.L: Her hand, I meane; And now 'e thee,
According to thy Councell giuen to her:
Saile by one Winde; Thou shalt, to one tune Sing,
Lie at one Guard, and Play but on one String,
Hencefoorth, I will Confine thee to one Garment,
And that shall be a cast one, Like thy selfe
Iust, past all Wearing, as thou past all Vse,
And not to be renewed, til't be as Ragged,
As thou art Rotten.

SP.SPEAKER: Bla.
SP.L: Nay sweet.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Lio.
SP.L: That for her Habbit.

SP.SPEAKER: Sca.
SP.L: A cold Sute, I haue on 't,

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Lio.
SP.L: To preuent Sursit,
They Diet, sha I bee to one Dish confin'd,
And that too Rifled, with as vncleane hands,
As ere were laid on thee.

SP.SPEAKER: Sca.
SP.L: What hee scants me in Victuals, would he but alow once in Drinke.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Lio.
SP.L: That shall be the refuse of the Flagons, Iaoks,
And Snuffes, such as the naftieft Breathes shall leaue;
Of Wine, and Strong-water, neuer hope,
Hencefoorth to Smell.

SP.SPEAKER: Sca.
SP.L: Oh me, I already.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Lio.
SP.L: If I since in my State, of all the rest,
Be thou excused, what thou proposed to her,
Beldam, is now against thy selfe decreed,
Drinke from drie springs, from empty, Knap-sacks fede.

SP.SPEAKER: Sca.
SP.L: No burnt Wine, nor Hot-waters.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Lio.
SP.L: Take her hence.

SP.SPEAKER: Bla.
SP.L: Indeede you are too cruell.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Lio.
SP.L: Yes to her,
Onely of purpose, to be kind to thee;
Are any of my Guests come?

SP.SPEAKER: Rio.
SP.L: Feare not Sir,
You will haue a fill Table.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Lio.
SP.L: What, and Musicke?

SP.SPEAKER: Rio.
SP.L: Best Consort in the Citie, for fixe parts.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Lio.
SP.L: Wee shall haue Songs then?

SP.SPEAKER: Rio.
SP.L: Bith' eare.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Lio.
SP.L: And Wenches?

SP.SPEAKER: Rio.
SP.L: Yes bith' eyc.

SP.SPEAKER: Bla.
SP.L: Ha, what was that you said?

SP.SPEAKER: Rio.
SP.L: We shall haue such to beare you company,
As will no doubt content you.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Lio.
SP.L: Enter then:
In Youth there is a Fate, that swayes vs still.
To know what's Good, and yet pursue what's Ill.

DIV3.HEAD: Scena Prima.
DIV3.STAGE: Enter old Master Wincott, and his Wife.

SP.SPEAKER: Winc.
SP.L: And what's this Dalauill?

SP.SPEAKER: Wife.
SP.L: My apprehension,
Can giue him no more true expression,
Then that he first appeares, a Gentleman,
And well conditioned.

SP.SPEAKER: Wino.
SP.L: That for outward shew;
But what in him haue you obserued else,
To make him better knowne?

SP.SPEAKER: Wife.
SP.L: I haue nor Eyes,
To search into the inward Thoughrs of Men,
Nor euer was studied in that 'Art,
To iudge of Meus affection by the face;
But that which makes me best opinion'd of him,
Is, That he's Companion, and the Friend
Beloued of him, whom you so much commend,
The Noble Master Geraldine,

SP.SPEAKER: Winc.
SP.L: Thou hast spoke,
That which not onely crownes his true desert,
But now instates him, in my better thoughts,
Making his Worth, vnquestioned.

SP.SPEAKER: Wife.
SP.L: Hee pretends
Loue to my sister Pru. I haue obseru'd him,
Single her out, to priuate conference.

SP.SPEAKER: Winc.
SP.L: But I could rather, for her owne sake, wish
Young Geraldine would fixe his thoughts that way,
And shee towards him; In such Affinity,
Trust me, I would not vse a sparing hand.

SP.SPEAKER: Wife.
SP.L: But Loue in these kindes, should not be compel'd,
Forc'd, nor Perswaded; When it freely Springs,
And of it selfe, takes voluntary Roote,
It Growes, it Spreads, it Ripens, and brings soorth,
Such an Vsurious Crop of timely Fruit,
As crownes a plentious Autume.

SP.SPEAKER: Winc.
SP.L: Such a Haruest,
I should not be th' vngladdest man to see,
Of all thy sisters friends: Now, whence come you?

SP.SPEAKER: Clo.
SP.P: Who, I Sir, From a Lodging of Lardgesse, a House of Hospita∣lity, and a Pallace of Plenty; Where there's Feeding like Horses, and Drinking like Fishes; Where for Pints, w'are serued in Pottles; and in stead of Pottle-pots, in Pailes; in stead of Siluer-tanckards, we drinke out of Water-tanckards; Clarret runs as freely, as the Cocks; and Canarie, like the Conduits of a Coronation day; Where there's no∣thing but Feeding and Frollicking; Caruing in Kissing; Drinking, and Dauncing; Musicke and Madding; Fidsing and Feasting.

SP.SPEAKER: Winc.
SP.P: And where, I pray thee, are all these Reuels kept?

SP.SPEAKER: Clo.
SP.P: They may be rather called Reakes then Reuells; As I came a∣long by the doore, I was call'd vp amongst them; Hee-Gallants, and Shee-Gallants, I no sooner look'd out; but saw them out with their Kniues, Slashing of Shoulders, Mangling of Legs, and Lanching of Loynes, till there was scarce a whole Limbe lest amongst them.

SP.SPEAKER: Winc.
SP.P: A fearefull Massacre.

SP.SPEAKER: Clo.
SP.P: One was Hacking to cut off a Necke, this was Mangling a Brest, his Knife slip from the Shoulder, and onely cut of a Wing, one was picking the Braines out of a Head, another was Knuckle deepe in a Belly, one was Groping for a Liuer, another Searching for the Kid∣neyes; I saw one plucke the Sole from the Body (Goose that she was to suffer't) another prickt into the Breast with his one Bill, Wood∣cocke to indure it.

SP.SPEAKER: Wife.
SP.P: How fell they out at first?

SP.SPEAKER: Clo.
SP.P: I know not that, but it seemes, one had a Stomacke, and ano∣ther had a Stomacke; But there was such biting and tearing with their teeths, that I am sure, I saw some of their poore Carcasses pay for't.

SP.SPEAKER: Winc.
SP.P: Did they not send for Surgeons?

SP.SPEAKER: Clo.
SP.P: Alas no, Surgeons helpe was too late; There was no stitching vp of those Wounds, where Limbe was pluckt from Limbe; Nor any Salue for those Scarrs, which all the Plaister of Paris cannot Cure.

SP.SPEAKER: Winc.
SP.P: Where grew the quarrell first?

SP.SPEAKER: Clo.
SP.P:
It seems it was first Broacht in the Kitchin; Certaine crea∣tures being brought in thither, by some of the House; The Cooke be∣ing a Colloricke fellow, did so Towse them and Tosse them, so Plucke them and Pull them, till hee left them as naked as my Naile, Pinioned some of them like Fellons; Cut the Spurres from others of their
Heeles; Then downe went his Spits, Some of them he ranne in at the Throat, and out at the Back-side; About went his Basting-Ladle, where he did so besawce them, that many a shrode turne they had amongst them.

SP.SPEAKER: Wife.
SP.P: But in all this, How did the Women scape?

SP.SPEAKER: Clo.
SP.P: They fared best, and did the least hurt that I saw; But for quietnesse sake, were forc'd to swallow what is not yet digested, yet euery one had their share, and shee that had least, I am sure by this time, hath her belly full.

SP.SPEAKER: Winc.
SP.P: And where was all this hauocke kept?

SP.SPEAKER: Clo.
SP.P: Marry Sir, at your next neighbours, Young Master Lionell, Where there is nothing but Drinking out of Dry-Fats, and Healthing in Halfe-Tubs, his Guests are fed by the Belly, and Beggers serued at his Gate in Baskets; Hee's the Adamant of this Age, the Daffadill of these dayes, the Prince of Prodigallity, and the very Caesar of all young Citizens.

SP.SPEAKER: Winc.
SP.P: Belike then, 'twas a Massacre of meat, not as I apprehended?

SP.SPEAKER: Clo.
SP.P: Your grauity hath gest aright; The chiefest that fell in this Battell, were wild Fowle and tame Fowle; Phessants were wounded in stead of Alfaresse, and Capons for Captaines, Anchoues stood for An∣tiants, and Cauiare for Corporals, Dishes were assaulted in stead of Ditches, and Rabbets were cut to pieces vpon the rebellings, some lost their Legs, whil'st other of their wings were forc'd to flie; The Pioner vndermind nothing but Pie-crust; And—

SP.SPEAKER: Winc.
SP.L: Enough, enough, your wit hath plai'd too long vpon our pa∣tience;
Wife, it grieues me much both for the yong and old man, the one,
Graces his head with care, endures the parching heat and biting cold,
The terrours of the Lands, and feares at Sea in trauell, onely to gaine
Some competent estate to leaue his sonne;
Whiles all that Merchandise, through Gulfes, Crosse-Tides,
Pitats and Stormes, he brings so farre; Th' other
Heere Shipwrackes in the Harbour.

SP.SPEAKER: Wife.
SP.L: Tis the care of Fathers; and the weakenesse
Incident to youth, that wants experience.

DIV3.STAGE: Enter Y. Geraldine, Dallauill, Prudentilla, langhing.

SP.SPEAKER: Clo.
SP.L: I was at the beginning of the Battell,
But heere comes some, that it seemes
Were at the rifling of the dead Carcasses;
For by their mirth, they haue had part of the Spoile.

SP.SPEAKER: Winc.
SP.L: Youare pleasant, Oendemen, what
Might be the Subiect of your pleasant sport,
It promiseth some pleasure?

SP.SPEAKER: Prud.
SP.L: If their recreation
Bee, as I make no question, on truth grounded,
'twill beger sudden laughter.

SP.SPEAKER: Wife.
SP.L: What's the Proiect?

SP.SPEAKER: Dal.
SP.L: Who shall relate it.

SP.SPEAKER: Winc.
SP.L: Master Geraldine, if there be any thing can please my Eare,
With pleasant soundes, your Tongue must be the Instrument,
On which the Sring must strike.

SP.SPEAKER: Dal.
SP.L: Bee't his then.

SP.SPEAKER: Prud.
SP.L: Nay heare it, 'tis a good one.

SP.SPEAKER: Wife
SP.L: Wee intreat you, Possesse vs oth' Nouell,

SP.SPEAKER: Winc.
SP.L: Speake, good Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Ger.
SP.L: I shall then, with a kind of Barbarisme,
Shaddow a Ieast, that askes a smoother Tongue,
For in my poore discourse, I doeprotest,
'twill but loose his luster.

SP.SPEAKER: Wife
SP.L: You are Modest.

SP.SPEAKER: Winc
SP.L: Howeuer speake, I pray; For my sake doo't?

SP.SPEAKER: Clo.
SP.P: This is like a hastie Pudding, longer in eating then it was in making.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Ger.
SP.L: Then thus it was, this Gentleman and I,
Past but iust now, by your next Neighbours house,
Where as they say, dwels one Young Lionell.

SP.SPEAKER: Clo.
SP.L: Where I was to night at Supper.

SP.SPEAKER: Winc.
SP.L: An vnthrist Youth, his Father now at Sea.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Ger.
SP.L: Why that's they very Subiect, vpon which
It seemes, this Iest is grounded, there this Night,
Was a great feast.

SP.SPEAKER: Clo.
SP.L: Why so I told you, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Winc.
SP.L: Bee thou still dumbe, 'tis-hee that I would heare.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Ger.
SP.L: In the height of their Carowsing, all their braines,
Warm'd with the heat of Wine; Discourse was offer'd,
Of Ships, and Stormes at Sea; when suddenly,
Out of his giddy wildnesse, one conceiues
The Roome wherein they quafft, to be a Pinnace,
Moouning and Floating; and the confused Noise,
To be the murmuring Windes, Gusts, Marriners;
That their vnstedfast Footing, did proced
From rocking of the Vessell: This conceiu'd,
Each one begins to apprehend the danger,
And to looke out for safety, flie saith one
Vp to the Manne-top, and discourer; Hee
Climbes by the bed post, to the Teaster, there
Reports a Turbulent Sea and Tempest towards;
And wills them if they'le saue their Ship and lines,
To cast their Lading ouer-board; At this
All fall to Worke, and Hoyste into the Street,
As to the Sea, What next come to their hand,
Stooles, Tables, Tressels, Trenchers, Bed-steds, Cups,
Pots, Plate, and Glasses; Heere a fellow Whistles,
They take him for the Boat-swaine, one lyes strugling
Vpon the floore, as if he swome for life,
A third, takes the Base-violl for the Cock-boate,
Sits in the belly on't, labours and Rowes;
His Oare, the Sticke with which the Fidler plaid;
A fourth, bestrides his Fellowes, thinking to scape
As did Arion, on the Dolphins backe,
Still fumbling on a gitterne.

SP.SPEAKER: Clo.
SP.L: Excellent Sport.

SP.SPEAKER: Winc.
SP.L: But what was the conclusion?

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Ger.
SP.L: The rude multiude,
Watching without, and gaping for the spoyle
Cast from the windowes, went bith' eares about it;
The Constable is called to Attone the broyle,
Which done, and hearing such a noise within,
Of eminent Ship-racke; enters the house, and finds them
In this confusion, They Adore his staffe,
And thinke it Neptunes Trident, and that hee
Comes with his Tritons, (so they cal'd his watch)
To calme the Tempest, and appease the Waues;
And at this point, wee left them.

SP.SPEAKER: Clo.
SP.L: Come what will, ile steale out of Doores,
And see the end of it, that 'scertaine.

SP.SPEAKER: Winc.
SP.L: Thanks Master Geraldine, for this discourse,
Introath it hath much pleased mee, but the night
Begins to grow faste on vs, for your parts,
You are all young, and you may sit vp late,
My eyes begin to summon me to sleepe,
And nothing's more offensiue vnto Age,
Then to watch long and late.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Ger.
SP.L: Now good Rest with you.

SP.SPEAKER: Dal.
SP.L: What saies faire Prudentilla? Maids and Widdows,
And wee young Batchelors, such as indeed
Are fore'd to lie in Solitary beds,
And sleepe without disturbance; wee methinks,
Should desire later houres; when Married Wines,
That in their amorus armes, hug their delights;
To often wakings subiect; their more hast,
May better be excused.

SP.SPEAKER: Prud.
SP.L: How can you,
That are as you confesse, a single man,
Enter so farre into these Misticall secrets
Of Mariage, which as yet you neuer prooued.

SP.SPEAKER: Dal.
SP.L: There's Lady, an instinct innate in man,
Which prompts vs to the apprehensions
Of th 'vses wee were borne to; Such we are
Aptest to learne; Ambitious most to know,
Of which our chiefe is Marriage.

SP.SPEAKER: Prud.
SP.L: What you Men
Most meditate, wee Women seldome dreame of.

SP.SPEAKER: Dal.
SP.L: When dreame Maids most?

SP.SPEAKER: Prud.
SP.L: When thinke you?

SP.SPEAKER: Dal.
SP.L: When you lie vpon your Backs, come come, your Eare.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Ger.
SP.L: Wee now are left alone.

SP.SPEAKER: Wife.
SP.L: Why say wee be who should be iealous of vs?
This is not first of many hundred Nights,
That wee two haue beene priuate, from the first
Of our acquaintance, when our Tongues but clipt
Our Mothers-tongue, and could not speake it plaine,
Wee knew each other; As in slatnre, so
Increast our sweet Societie; Since your trauell,
And my late Marriage, Through my Husbands lone,
Mid-night hath beene as Mid-day, and my Bed-chamber,
As free to you, as your owne Fathers house,
And you as welcome too 't.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Ger.
SP.L: I must confesse,
It is in you, your Noble Courtesie,
In him, a more then common considence,
And in this Age, canscarce find president.

SP.SPEAKER: Wife.
SP.L: Most trew, it is withall an Argument,
That both our vertues are so deepe imprest
In his good thoughts, hee knowes we cannot erre.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Ger.
SP.L: A villaine were hee, to deceiue such trust,
Or (were there one) a much worse Carracter.

SP.SPEAKER: Wife.
SP.L: And she no lesse, whom either Beauty, Youth,
Time, Place, or opportunity could tempt,
To iniure such a Husband.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Ger.
SP.L: You deserue, euen for his sake, to be for euer young;
And hee for yours, to haue his Youth reuew'd;
So mutuall is your trew coniugall Loue; Yet had the Fates so pleas'd

SP.SPEAKER: Wife.
SP.L: I know your meaning,
It was once voyc'd, that wee two should haue Matcht,
The World so thought, and many Tongues so spake,
But Heauen hath now dispos'd vs otherwayes;
And being as it is, (a thing in me,
Which I protest, was neuer wisht, nor sought)
Now done, I not repent it.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Ger.
SP.L: In those times,
Of all the Treasures of my Hopes and Loue,
You were th' Exchequer, they were Stor'd in you;
And had not my vnfortunate Trauell crost them,
They had bin heere reserued still.

SP.SPEAKER: Wife.
SP.L: Troath they had,
I should haue beene your trusty Treasurer.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Ger.
SP.L: Howeuer let vs Loue still, I intreat:
That, Neighbour-hood and breeding will allow;
So much the Lawes Diuine and Humaine both,
Twixt Brother and a Sister will approue;
Heauen then forbid, that they should limit vs
Wish well to one another.

SP.SPEAKER: Wife.
SP.L: If they should not,
Wee might proclaime, they were not Charitable,
Which were a deadly fin but to conceiue.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Ger.
SP.L: Will you resolue me one thing?

SP.SPEAKER: Wife.
SP.P: As to one, that in my Bosome hath a second place, next my deere Husband.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Ger.
SP.L: That's the thing I craue,
And onely that, to haue a place next him.

SP.SPEAKER: Wife.
SP.L: Presume on that already, but perhaps,
You meane to stretch it further.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Ger.
SP.L: Onely thus farre,
Your Husbands old, to whom my Soule doth wish,
A Nesters age, So much he merits from me;
Yet if (as proofe and Nature daily teach)
Men cannot alwayes liue, especially
Such as are old and Crazed; Hee be cal'd hence,
Fairely, in full maturity of time,
And we two be reseru'd to after life,
Will you conferre your Widow-hood on mee?

SP.SPEAKER: Wife.
SP.L: You aske the thing, I was about to beg;
Your tongue hath spake mine owne thoughts.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Ger.
SP.L: Vow to that.

SP.SPEAKER: Wife.
SP.L: As I hope Mercy.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Ger.
SP.L: 'Tis enough, that word
Alone, instates me happy; Now so please you,
Wee will diuide, you to your priuate Chamber,
I to find out my friend.

SP.SPEAKER: Wife.
SP.L: Nay Master Geraldine, one Ceremonie rests yet vnperform'd,
My Vow is past, your oath must next proceed,
And as you couet to be sure of me,
Of you I would be certaine.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Ger.
SP.L: Make ye doubt?

SP.SPEAKER: Wife.
SP.L: No doubt; but Lone's still Iealous, and in that
To be excused; You then shall sweare by Heauen,
And as in all your future Acts, you hope
To thriue and prosper; As the Day may yeeld
Comfort, or the Night rest, as you would keepe
Entire, the Honour of your Fathers house,
And free your Name from Scandall and Reproach,
By all the Goodnesse that you hope to enioy,
Or ill to shun—

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Ger.
SP.L: You charge me deeply Lady.

SP.SPEAKER: Wife.
SP.L: Till that day come, you shall reserue your selfe
A single man; Conuerse nor company
With any Woman, Contract nor Combine,
With Maid, or Widow; which expected houre,
As I doe wish not haste, so when it happens,
It shall not come vnwelcome; You here all, Vow this.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Ger.
SP.P: By all that you haue said, I sweare, and by this Kisse Confirme.

SP.SPEAKER: Wife.
SP.L: Y'are now my Brother,
But then, my second Husband.

DIV3.STAGE: Enter Y. Lionell, Rioter, Blanda, Scapha, two Gallants, and two Wenches, as newly wak'd from sleepe.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Lio.
SP.L: Wee had a stormy night on't.

SP.SPEAKER: Bla.
SP.L: The Wine still workes,
And with the little rest they haue tooke to night,
They are scarce come to themselues.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Lio.
SP.L: Now 'tis a Calme,
Thankes to those gentle Sea-gods, that haue brought vs
To this safe Harbour; Can you tell their names?

SP.SPEAKER: Sca.
SP.L: He with the Painted-staffe, I heard you call Neptune.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Lio.
SP.L: The dreadfull god of Seas,
Vpon whose backe neere stucke March flees.

SP.SPEAKER: 1. Gall.
SP.L: One with the Bill, keepes Neptunes Porposes,
So Ouid sayes in's Metamorphosis.

SP.SPEAKER: 2. Gall.
SP.L: A third the learned Poets write on,
And as they say, His name is Triton.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Lio.
SP.L: These are the Marine gods, to whom my father
In his long voyage prayes too; Cannot they
That brought vs to our Hauen, bury him
In their Abisse? For if he safe ariue,
I with these Sailors, Syrens, and what not,
Am sure heere to be shipwrackt.

SP.SPEAKER: 1. Wen.
SP.L: Stand vp stiffe.

SP.SPEAKER: Rio.
SP.L: But that the ship so totters: I shall fall.

SP.SPEAKER: 1. Wen.
SP.L: If thou fall, Ile fall with thee.

SP.SPEAKER: Rio.
SP.L: Now I sincke,
And as I diue and drowne, Thus by degrees,
Ile plucke thee to the bottome.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Lio.
SP.L: A maine for England, See, see,
The Spaniard now strikes Saile.

SP.SPEAKER: Reig.
SP.L: So must you all.

SP.SPEAKER: 1. Gall.
SP.L: Whence is your ship, from the Bermoothes?

SP.SPEAKER: Reig.
SP.L: Worse, I thinke from Hell:
We are all Lost, Split, Shipwrackt, and vndone,
This place is a meere quick-sands.

SP.SPEAKER: 2. Gall.
SP.L: So we feared.

SP.SPEAKER: Reig.
SP.L: Wher's my young Master?

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Lio.
SP.L: Heere man, speake, the Newes?

SP.SPEAKER: Reig.
SP.L: The Newes is, I, and you—

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Lio.
SP.L: What?

SP.SPEAKER: Reig.
SP.L: Shee, and all these—

SP.SPEAKER: Bla.
SP.L: I?

SP.SPEAKER: Reig.
SP.L: We, and all ours, are in one turbulent Sea
Of Feare, Dispaire, Disaster and mischance swallowed:
Your father, Sir—

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Lio.
SP.L: Why, what of him?

SP.SPEAKER: Reig.
SP.L: He is, Oh I want breath.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Lio.
SP.L: Where?

SP.SPEAKER: Reig.
SP.L: Landed, and at hand.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Lio.
SP.L: Vpon what coast? Who saw him?

SP.SPEAKER: Reig.
SP.L: I, these eyes.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Lio.
SP.L: Oh Heauen, what shall I doe then?

SP.SPEAKER: Reig.
SP.L: Aske ye me what shall become of you, that haue not yet
Had time of studdy to dispose my selfe;
I say againe, I was vpon the Key,
I saw him land, and this way bend his course;
What drunkard's this, that can out sleepe a storme
Which threatens all our ruines? Wake him.

SP.SPEAKER: Ela.
SP.L: Ho, Rioter, awake.

SP.SPEAKER: Rio.
SP.L: Yes, I am wake;
How dry hath this Salt-water made me; Boy,
Giue me th' other Glasse.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Lio.
SP.L: Arise, I say,
My Fathers come from Sea.

SP.SPEAKER: Rio.
SP.L: If he be come, Bid him be gone againe.

SP.SPEAKER: Reig.
SP.L: Can you trifle at such a time, when your Inuentions.
Braines, Wits, Plots, Deuices, Stratagems, and all
Should be at one in action? each of you
That loue your safeties, lend your helping hands,
Women and all, to take this drunkard hence,
And to bestow him else where.

SP.SPEAKER: Bla.
SP.L: Lift for Heauens sake.

SP.SPEAKER: Reig.
SP.L: But what am I the neerer, were all these
Conuey'd to sundry places and vnseene;
The staine of our disorders still remaine,
Of which, the house will wirnesse, and the old man
Must finde when he enters; And for these
I am here left to answere: What is he gone?

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Lio.
SP.L: But whither? But into th' selfe same house
That harbours him; my Fathers, where we all
Attend from him surpriseall.

SP.SPEAKER: Reig.
SP.L: I will make
That Prison of your feares, your Sanctuary;
Goe get you in together.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Lio.
SP.L: To this house?

SP.SPEAKER: Reig.
SP.L: Your Fathers, with your Sweet-heart, these and all;
Nay, no more words but doo't,

SP.SPEAKER: Bla.
SP.L: That were to betray vs to his fury.

SP.SPEAKER: Reig.
SP.L: I haue't heere,
To Baile you hence at pleasure; and in th' interim,
Ile make this supposed Goale, to you, as safe
From th' iniur'd old mans iust incensed spleene,
As were you now together ith' Low-Countreyes,
Viriginia, or ith' Indies.

SP.SPEAKER: Bla.
SP.L: Present feare,
Bids vs to yeeld vnto the faint beliefe
Of the least hoped safety.

SP.SPEAKER: Reig.
SP.L: Will you in?

SP.SPEAKER: Omn.
SP.L: By thee we will be counsell'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Reig.
SP.L: Shut them fast.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Lio.
SP.L: And thou and I to leaue them?

SP.SPEAKER: Reig.
SP.P: No such thing, for you shall beare your Sweet-heart com∣pany, And helpe to cheere the rest.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Lio.
SP.L: And so thou
Meanest to escape alone?

SP.SPEAKER: Reig.
SP.L: Rather without,
Ile stand a Champion for you all within;
Will you be swai'd? One thing in any case
I must aduise; The gates boulted and lockt,
See that 'mongst you no liuing voyce be heard;
No not so much as a Dog to howle,
Or Cat to mewe, all silence, that I charge;
As if this were a meere forsaken house,
And none did there inhabite.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Lio.
SP.L: Nothing else?

SP.SPEAKER: Reig.
SP.L: And though the old man thunder at the gates
As if he meant to ruine what he had rear'd,
None on their liues to answere.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Lio.
SP.L: 'Tis my charge;
Remaines there nothing else?

SP.SPEAKER: Reig.
SP.P: Onely the Key; for I must play the goaler for your durance, To bee the Mercurie in your release.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Lio.
SP.L: Me and my hope, I in this Key deliuer
To thy safe trust.

SP.SPEAKER: Reig.
SP.L: When you are fast you are safe,
And with this turne 'tis done: What fooles are these,
To trust their ruin'd fortunes to his hands
That hath betrai'd his owne; And make themselues
Prisoner to one deserues to lie for all,
As being cause of all; And yet something prompts me,
Ile stand it at all dangers; And to recompence
The many wrongs vnto the yong man done:
Now, if I can doubly delude the old,
My braine, about it then; All's husht within,
The noise that shall be, I must make without;
And he that part for gaine, and part for wit,
So farre hath trauell'd, striue to foole at home:
Which to effect, Art must with Knauery ioyne,
And smooth Dissembling meet with Impudence;
He doe my best, and howsoere it prooue,
My praise or shame, 'tis but a seruants loue.

DIV3.STAGE: Enter old Lionell like a ciuill Merchant, with Water-men, and two seruants with Burdens and Caskets.

SP.SPEAKER: Old Lio.
SP.L: Discharge these honest Sailors that haue brought
Our Chests a shore, and pray them haue a care,
Those merchandise be safe we left aboord:
As Heauen hath blest vs with a fortunate Voyage,
In which we bring home riches with our healthes,
So let not vs prooue niggards in our store;
See them paid well, and to their full content.

SP.SPEAKER: 1. Ser.
SP.L: I shall Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Old Lio.
SP.L: Then returne: These speciall things,
And of most value, weele not trust aboord;
Meethinkes they are not safe till they see home,
And there repose, where we will rest our selues,
And bid farewell to Trauell; for I vow,
After this houre, no more to trust the Seas,
Nor throw mee to such danger.

SP.SPEAKER: Reig.
SP.L: I could wish
You had tooke your leaue oth' Land too.

SP.SPEAKER: Old Lio.
SP.L: And now it much reioyceth me, to thinke
What a most sudden welcome I shall bring,
both to my Friends and priuate Family.

SP.SPEAKER: Reig.
SP.L: Oh, but how much more welcome had he beene,
That had brought certaine tidings of thy death.

SP.SPEAKER: Old Lio.
SP.L: But soft, what's this? my owne gates shut vpon me,
And barre their Master entrance? Whose within there?
How, no man speake, are all asleepe or dead,
That no soule stirres to open?

SP.SPEAKER: Reig.
SP.L: What madde man's that, who weary of his life,
Dares once lay hand on these accursed gates?

SP.SPEAKER: Old Lio.
SP.L: Whose that? my seruant Reignald.

SP.SPEAKER: Reig.
SP.L: My old Master,
Most glad I am to see you; Are you well Sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Old Lio.
SP.L: Thou see'st I am.

SP.SPEAKER: Reig.
SP.L: But are you sure you are?
Feele you no change about you? Pray you stand off.

SP.SPEAKER: Old Lio.
SP.L: What strange and vnexpected greetings this,
That thus a man may knocke at his owne gates,
Beat with his hands and feet, and call thus loud,
And no man giue him entrance?

SP.SPEAKER: Reig.
SP.L: Said you Sir;
Did your hand touch that hammer?

SP.SPEAKER: Old Lio.
SP.L: Why, whose else?

SP.SPEAKER: Reig.
SP.L: But are you sure you toucht it?

SP.SPEAKER: Old Lio.
SP.L: How else, I prethee, could I haue made this noise?

SP.SPEAKER: Reig.
SP.L: You toucht it then?

SP.SPEAKER: Old Lio.
SP.L: I tell thee yet I did.

SP.SPEAKER: Reig.
SP.L: Oh for the loue I beare you,
Oh me most miserable, you, for you owne sake,
Of all aliue most wretched; Did you touch it?

SP.SPEAKER: Old Lio.
SP.L: Why, say I did?

SP.SPEAKER: Reig.
SP.L: You haue then a sinne committed,
No sacrifice can expiate to the Dead;
But yet I hope you did not.

SP.SPEAKER: Old Lio.
SP.L: 'Tis past hope,
The deed is done, and I repent it not.

SP.SPEAKER: Reig.
SP.L: You and all yours will doo't. In this one rashnes,
You haue vndone vs all; Pray be not desperate,
But first thanke Heauen that you haue escapt thus well;
Come from the gate, yet further, further yet,
And tempt your fate no more; Command your seruants
Giue off and come no neerer, they are ignorant,
And doe not know the danger, therefore pity
That they should perish in 't; 'Tis full seuen moneths,
Since any of your house durst oce set foot
Ouer that threshold.

SP.SPEAKER: Old Lio.
SP.L: Prethee speake the cause?

SP.SPEAKER: Reig.
SP.L: First looke about, beware that no man heare,
Command these to remooue.

SP.SPEAKER: Old Lio.
SP.L: Be gone. Exit Seruants. Now speake.

SP.SPEAKER: Reig.
SP.L: Oh Sir, This house is growne Prodigious,
Fatall, Disasterous vnto you and yours.

SP.SPEAKER: Old. Lio.
SP.L: What Fatall? what Disasterous?

SP.SPEAKER: Reig.
SP.L: Some Host that hath beene owner of this house,
In it his Guest hath slaine; And we suspect
'Twas he of whom you bought it.

SP.SPEAKER: Old Lio.
SP.L: How came this
Discouer'd to you first?

SP.SPEAKER: Reig.
SP.L: Ile tell you Sir,
But further from the gate: Your sonne one night
Suppt late abroad, I within; Oh that night,
I neuer shall forget; Being safe got home,
I saw him in his chamber laid to rest;
And after went to mine, and being drowsie,
Forgot by chance, to put the Candle out;
Being dead asleepe; Your sonne affrighted, calls
So loud, that I soone waken'd; Brought in light,
And found him almost drown'd in fearefull sweat;
Amaz'd to see't, I did demand the cause:
Who told me, that this murdered Ghost appeared,
His body gasht, and all ore-stucke with wounds;
And spake to him as followes.

SP.SPEAKER: Old Lio.
SP.L: Oh proceed, 'tis that I long to heare.

SP.SPEAKER: Reig.
SP.L: I am, quoth he,
A Trans-marine by birth, who came well stored
With Gold and Iewels, to this fatall house;
Where seeking safety, I encounter'd death:
The couetous Merchant, Land-lord of this rent,
To whom I gaue my life and wealth in charge;
Freely to enioy the one, rob'd me of both:
Heere was my body buried, here my Ghost
Must euer walke, till that haue Christian right;
Till when, my habitation must be here:
Then flie yong man, Remooue thy family,
And secke some safer dwelling: For my death,
This mansion is accurst; 'Tis my possession,
Bought at the deere rate of my life and blood,
None enter here, that aymes at his owne good.
And with this charge he vanisht.

SP.SPEAKER: Old Lio.
SP.L: Oh my feare,
Whither wilt thou transport me?

SP.SPEAKER: Reig.
SP.L: I Intreat keepe further from the gate, and flie.

SP.SPEAKER: Old Lio.
SP.L: Flie whither? Why doest not thou flie too?

SP.SPEAKER: Reig.
SP.L: What need I feare, the Ghost and I am friends.

SP.SPEAKER: Old Lio.
SP.L: But Reignald.

SP.SPEAKER: Reig.
SP.L: Tush, I nothing haue deserued,
Nor ought transgrest: I came not neere the gate.

SP.SPEAKER: Old Lio.
SP.L: To whom was that thou spakest?

SP.SPEAKER: Reig.
SP.L: Was't you Sir nam'd me?
Now as I liue, I thought the dead man call'd,
To enquire for him that thunder'd at the gate
Which he so dearely pai'd for: Are you madd,
To stand a fore-seene danger?

SP.SPEAKER: Old Lio.
SP.L: What shall I doe?

SP.SPEAKER: Reig.
SP.L: Couer you head and flie; Lest looking backe,
You spie your owne confusion.

SP.SPEAKER: Old Lio.
SP.L: Why doest not thou flie too?

SP.SPEAKER: Reig.
SP.L: I tell you Sir,
The Ghost and I am friends.

SP.SPEAKER: Old Lio.
SP.L: Why didst thou quake then?

SP.SPEAKER: Reig.
SP.L: In feare lest some mischance may fall on you,
That haue the dead offended, For my part,
The Ghost and I am friends: Why flie you not,
Since here you are not safe?

SP.SPEAKER: Old Lio.
SP.L: Some blest powers guard me.

SP.SPEAKER: Reig.
SP.L: Nay Sir, ile not forsake you: I haue got the start;
But ete the goale, 'twill aske both Braine and Art.

DIV3.HEAD: Seena Prima.
DIV3.STAGE: Enter old Master Geraldine, Y. Geraldine, Master Wincott, and Wife, Dalauill, Prudentilla.

SP.SPEAKER: Winc.
SP.L: We are bound to you, kind Master Geraldine,
For this great entertainement; Troath your cost
Hath much exceeded common neighbour-hood:
You haue feasted vs like Princes.

SP.SPEAKER: Old Ger.
SP.L: This, and more
Many degrees, can neuer counteruaile
The oft and frequent welcomes giuen my sonne:
You haue tooke him from me quite, and haue I thinke,
Adopted him into your family,
He staies with me so seldome.

SP.SPEAKER: Win.
SP.L: And in this,
By trusting him to me, of whom your selfe
May haue both vse and pleasure, y'are as kind
As money'd men, that might make benefit
Of what they are possest, yet to their friends
In need, will lend it gratis.

SP.SPEAKER: Wife.
SP.L: And like such,
As are indebted more then they can pay;
Wee more and more confesse our selues engaged
To you, for your forbearance.

SP.SPEAKER: Prud.
SP.L: Yet you see,
Like Debtors, such as would not breake their day;
The Treasure late receiued, wee tender backe,
The which, the longer you can spare, you still
The more shall binde vs to you.

SP.SPEAKER: Old Ger.
SP.L: Most kind Ladies,
Worthy you are to borrow, that returne
The Principall, with such large vse of thanks.

SP.SPEAKER: Dal.
SP.L: What strange felicitie these Rich men take,
To talke of borrowing, lending, and of vse;
The vsurers language right.

SP.SPEAKER: Winc.
SP.L: Y'aue Master Geraldine,
Faire walkes and gardens, I haue praised them,
Both to my Wife and Sister.

SP.SPEAKER: Old Ger.
SP.L: You would see them,
There's no pleasure that the House can yeeld,
That can be debar'd from you; prethee Sonne,
Be thou the Vsher to those Mounts and Prospects
May one day call thee Master.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Ger.
SP.L: Sir I shall; Please you to walke.

SP.SPEAKER: Prud.
SP.L: What Master Dalauill,
Will you not beare vs company.

SP.SPEAKER: Dal.
SP.L: 'Tis not fit
That wee should leaue our Noble host alone,
Be you my Friends charge, and this old man mine.

SP.SPEAKER: Prud.
SP.L: Well, bee't then at your pleasure.

SP.SPEAKER: Dal.
SP.L: You to your Prospects, bt there's proiect heere
That's of another Nature; Worthy Sir,
I cannot but approue your happinesse,
To be the Father of so braue a Sonne,
So euery way accomplish't and made vp,
In which my voice is least; For I alasse,
Beare but a meane part in the common quier,
When with much lowder accents of his praise,
So all the world reports him.

SP.SPEAKER: Old Ger.
SP.L: Thanke my Starres,
They haue lent me one, who as he alwayes was,
And is my present ioy; If their aspect
Be no wayes to our goods Maleuolent,
May be my Future comfort.

SP.SPEAKER: Dal.
SP.L: Yet must I hold him happie aboue others,
As one that Solie to himselfe inioyes
What many others aime at; But in vaine.

SP.SPEAKER: Old Ger.
SP.L: How meane you that?

SP.SPEAKER: Dal.
SP.L: So Beautifull a Mistresse.

SP.SPEAKER: Old Ger.
SP.L: A Mistresse, said you?

SP.SPEAKER: Dal.
SP.L: Yes Sir, or a Friend,
Whether you please to stile her.

SP.SPEAKER: Old Ger.
SP.L: Mistresse? Friend?
Pray be more open languag'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Dal.
SP.L: And indeed,
Who can blame him to absent himselfe from home,
And make his Fathers house but as a grange,
For a Beautie so Attractiue? Or blame her,
Huging so weake an old Man in her armes,
To make a new choice, of an equall youth,
Being in him so Perfect? yet introath,
I thinke they both are honest.

SP.SPEAKER: Old Ger.
SP.L: You haue Sir,
Possest me with such strange sancies.

SP.SPEAKER: Dal.
SP.L: For my part,
How can I loue the person of your Sonne,
And not his reputation? His repaire
So often to the House, is voyct by all,
And frequent in the mouthes of the whole Countrey,
Some equally addicted, praise his happinesse;
But others, more Censorious and Austere,
Blame and reprooue a course so disolute;
Each one in generall, pittie the good man,
As one vnfriendly dealt with, yet in my conscience,
I thinke them truely Honest.

SP.SPEAKER: Old Ger.
SP.L: 'Tis suspitious.

SP.SPEAKER: Dal.
SP.L: True Sir, at best; But what when scandalons tongues
Will make the worst? and what good in it selfe,
Sullie and staine by fabulous mis-report;
For let men liue as charie as they can,
Their liues are often questioned, Then no wonder,
If such as giue occasion of suspition,
Be subiect to this scandall: What I speake,
Is as a Noble Friend vnto your Sonne;
And therefore, as I glory in his Fame,
I suffer in his wrong; for as I liue,
I thinke, they both are honest.

SP.SPEAKER: Old Ger.
SP.L: Howsoeuer, I wish them so.

SP.SPEAKER: Dal.
SP.L: Some course might be deuis'd,
To stop this clamor ere it grow too wrancke;
Lest that which yet but inconuenience seemes,
May turne to greater mischiefe; This I speake
In Zeale to both, in soueraine care of him
As of a Friend; And tender of her Honour,
As one to whom I hope to be allyed,
By Marriage with her Sister.

SP.SPEAKER: Old Ger.
SP.L: I much thanke you,
For you haue cleerely giuen me light of that,
Till now I neuer dreamt on.

SP.SPEAKER: Dal.
SP.L: 'Tis my Loue,
And therefore I intreat you, make not mee
To be the first reporter.

SP.SPEAKER: Old Ger.
SP.L: You haue done
The office of a Noble Gentleman,
And shall not be so iniur'd.

DIV3.STAGE: Enter againe as from Walking Winc. Wife, Y. Ger. Prud.

SP.SPEAKER: Winc.
SP.L: See Master Geraldine,
How bold wee are, especially these Ladies
Play little better then the theeues with you,
For they haue robb'd your Garden.

SP.SPEAKER: Wife.
SP.L: You might Sir,
Better haue term'd it saucenes, then theft;
You see we blush not, what we tooke in priuate,
To weare in publicke view.

SP.SPEAKER: Prud.
SP.L: Besides, these cannot
Be mist out of so many; In full fields,
The gleanings are allow'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Old Ger.
SP.L: These and the rest,
Are Ladies, at your seruice.

SP.SPEAKER: Winc.
SP.L: Now to horse,
But one thing ere wee part, I must intreat;
In which my Wife will be ioynt suter with me,
My Sister too.

SP.SPEAKER: Old Ger.
SP.L: In what I pray.

SP.SPEAKER: Winc.
SP.L: That hee
Which brought vs hither, may but bring vs home;
Your much respected Sonne.

SP.SPEAKER: Old Ger.
SP.L: How men are borne,
To woe their owne disasters?

SP.SPEAKER: Wife
SP.L: But to see vs
From whence he brought vs Sir, that's all.

SP.SPEAKER: Old Ger.
SP.L: This second motion makes it Palpable:
To note a Womans cunning; Make her husband
Bawde to her owne laciuious appetite,
And to Solicite his owne shame.

SP.SPEAKER: Prud.
SP.L: Nay Sir,
When all of vs ioyne in so small a suit,
It were some iniurie to be deni'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Old Ger.
SP.L: And worke her Sister too; What will not woman
To accomplish her owne ends: But this disease,
Ile seeke to Phisicke ere it grow too farre:
I am most sorrie to be vrg'd sweet Friends,
In what at this time I can no wayes grant;
Most, that these Ladies should be ought deni'd,
To whom I owe all Seruice, but occasions
Of weighty and important conscequence,
Such as concerne the best of my Estate,
Call him aside; excuse vs both this once,
Presume this businesse is no sooner ouer,
But hee's at his owne freedome.

SP.SPEAKER: Winc.
SP.L: 'Twere no manners
In vs to vrge it further, wee will leaue you,
With promise Sir, that he shall in my will,
Not be the last remembred.

SP.SPEAKER: Old. Ger.
SP.L: Wee are bound to you;
See them to Horse, and instantly returne,
Wee haue Imployments for you.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Ger.
SP.L: Sir I shall,

SP.SPEAKER: Dal.
SP.L: Remember your last promise,

SP.SPEAKER: Old Ger.
SP.L: Not to doo't, I should forget my selfe:
If I finde him false
To such a friend, be sure he forfeits me;
In which to be more punctually resolu'd,
I haue a proiect how to fift his foule,
How 'tis enclin'd; whether to yonder place,
The cleare bright Pallace, or blacke Dungeon: See,
They are onward on the way, and hee return'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Ger.
SP.L: I now attend your pleasure.

SP.SPEAKER: Old Ger.
SP.L: You are growne perfect man, and now you float
Like to a well built Vessell; 'Tweene two Currents,
Vertue and Vice; Take this, you steere to harbour;
Take that, to eminent shipwracke.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Ger.
SP.L: Pray your meaning.

SP.SPEAKER: Old Ger.
SP.L: What fathers cares are, you shall neuer know,
Till you your selfe haue children; Now my studdy,
Is how to make you such, that you in them
May haue a feeling of my loue to you.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Ger.
SP.L: Pray Sir expound your selfe, for I protest
Of all the Languages I yet haue learth'd,
This is to me most forraine.

SP.SPEAKER: Old Ger.
SP.L: Then I shall;
I haue liued to see you in your prime of youth
And height of Fortune, so you will but take
Occasion by the forehead; to be briefe,
And cut off all superfluous circumstance,
All the ambition that I ayme at now,
Is but to see you married.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Ger.
SP.L: Married Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Old. Ger.
SP.L: And to that purpose, I haue found out one,
Whose Youth and Beauty may not onely please
A curious eye; But her immediate meanes,
Able to strengthen a state competent,
Or raise a ruined Fortune.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Ger.
SP.L: Of all which,
I haue beleeue me, neither need nor vse;
My competence best pleasing as it is;
And this my singularity of life,
Most to my mind contenting.

SP.SPEAKER: Od Ger.
SP.L: I suspect, but yet must prooue him further;
Say to my care I adde a Fathers charge,
And couple with my counsell my command:
To that how can you answere?

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Ger.
SP.L: That I hope:
My duty and obedience still vnblam'd,
Did neuer merit such austerity;
And from a father neuer yet displeas'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Old Ger.
SP.L: Nay, then to come more neere vnto the point,
Either you must resolue for present marriage,
Or forfeit all your interest in my loue.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Ger.
SP.L: Vn-say that language, I intreat you Sir,
And doe not so oppresse me; Or if needs
Your heauy imposition stand in force,
Resolue me by your counsell; With more safety
May I infringe a sacred vow to heauen,
Or to oppose me to your strict command?
Since one of these I must.

SP.SPEAKER: Old Ger.
SP.L: Now Dalauill,
I finde thy words too true.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Ger.
SP.L: For marrie, Sir, I neither may, nor can.

SP.SPEAKER: Old Ger.
SP.L: Yet whore you may;
And that's no brech of any vow to Heauen:
Pollute the Nuptiall bed with Michall sinne;
Asperse the honour of a noble friend;
Forfeit thy reputation, here below.
And th' interest that thy Soule might claime aboue,
In you blest City: These you may, and can,
With vntoucht conscience: Oh, that I should liue
to see the hopes that I haue stor'd so long;
Thus in a moment ruin'd: And the staffe,
On which my old decrepite age should leane;
Before my face thus broken: On which trusting,
I thus abortiuely, before my time,
Fall headlong to my Graue.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Ger.
SP.L: It yet stands strong;
Both to support you vnto future life,
And fairer comfort.

SP.SPEAKER: Old Ger.
SP.L: Neuer, neuer sonne:
For till thou canst acquit thy selfe of scandall,
And me of my suspition; Heere, euen heere,
Where I haue measur'd out my length of earth;
I shall expire my last.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Ger.
SP.L: Both these I can:
Then rise Sir, I intreat you; And that innocency,
Which poyson'd by the breath of Calumnie, cast you thus low,
Shall, these few staines wipt off, with better thoughts erect you.

SP.SPEAKER: Old Ger.
SP.L: Well, Say on.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Ger.
SP.L: There's but one fire from which this smoake may grow;
Namely, the vnmatcht yoake of youth; And
In which, If euer I occasion was,
Of the smalest breach; The greatest implacable mischiefe
Adultery can threaten, fall on me;
Of you may I be disauow'd a sonne;
And vnto Heauen a seruant: For that Lady,
As she is Beauties mirror, so I hold her
For Chastities examples: From her tongue,
Neuer came language, that ariued my eare,
That euen censurious Cato, liu'd he now,
Could mis-interpret; Neuer from her lips,
Came vnchaste kisse; Or from her constant eye,
Looke sauouring of the least immodesty: Further—

SP.SPEAKER: Old Ger.
SP.P: Enough; One onely thing remaines, which on thy part per∣form'd, Assures firme credit to these thy protestations.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Ger.
SP.L: Name it then.

SP.SPEAKER: Old Ger.
SP.L: Take hence th' occasion of this common fame;
Which hath already spread it selfe so farre,
To her dishonour and thy preiudice, From this day forward,
To forbeare the house: This doe vpon my blessing.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Ger.
SP.L: As I hope it, I will not faile your charge.

SP.SPEAKER: Old. Ger.
SP.L: I am satisfied.

DIV3.STAGE: Enter at one doore an Vsurer and his Man, at the other, Old Lionell with his seruant: In the midst Reignald.

SP.SPEAKER: Reig.
SP.L: To which hand shall I turne me; Here's my Master
Hath bin to enquire of him that sould the house,
Touching the murder; Here's an Vsuring-Rascall,
Of whom we haue borrowed money to supply
Our prodigall expences; Broke our day,
And owe him still the Principall and Vse:
Were I to meet them single, I haue braine
To oppose both, and to come off vnscarr'd;
But if they doe assault me, and at once.
Not Hercules himselfe could stand that odds:
Therefore I must encounter them by turnes;
And to my Master first: Oh Sir, well met.

SP.SPEAKER: Old Lio.
SP.L: What Reignald; I but now met with the man,
Of whom I bought you house.

SP.SPEAKER: Reig.
SP.L: What, did you Sir?
But did you speake of ought concerning that
Which I last told you?

SP.SPEAKER: Old Lio.
SP.L: Yes, I told him all.

SP.SPEAKER: Reig.
SP.L: Then am I cast: But I pray tell me Sir,
Did he confesse the murder?

SP.SPEAKER: Old Lio.
SP.L: No such thing; Most stiffely he denies it.

SP.SPEAKER: Reig.
SP.L: Impudent wretch; Then serue him with a warrant, let the Of∣ficer
Bring him before a Iustice, you shall heare
What I can say against him; Sfoot deni't:
But I pray Sir excuse me, yonder's one
With whom I haue some businesse; Stay you here,
And but determine what's best course to take,
And note how I will follow't.

SP.SPEAKER: Old Lio.
SP.L: Be briefe then.

SP.SPEAKER: Reg.
SP.L: Now, If I can aswell put off my Vse-man,
This day, I shall be master of the field.

SP.SPEAKER: Vsu.
SP.L: That should be Lionells man.

SP.SPEAKER: Man
SP.L: The ame, I know him.

SP.SPEAKER: Vsu.
SP.L: After so many friolous delaies,
There's now some hope. He that was wont to shun vs,
And to absent himselfe, accoasts vs freely;
And with a pleasant countenance: Well met Reignald,
What's this money ready?

SP.SPEAKER: Reig.
SP.L: Neuer could you
Haue come in better time.

SP.SPEAKER: Vsu.
SP.P: Where's your master, yong Lionell, it something troubles me, That hee should breake his day.

SP.SPEAKER: Reig.
SP.L: A word in priuate,

SP.SPEAKER: Vsu.
SP.L: Tush, Priuate me no priuates, in a word,
Speake, are my moneys ready?

SP.SPEAKER: Reig.
SP.L: Not so loud.

SP.SPEAKER: Vsu.
SP.L: I will be louder yet; Giue me my moneys,
Come, tender me my moneys.

SP.SPEAKER: Reig.
SP.P: We know you haue a throat, wide as your consience; You need not vse it now—Come, get you home.

SP.SPEAKER: Vsu.
SP.L: Home?

SP.SPEAKER: Reig.
SP.L: Yes, home I say, returne by three a Clocke,
And I will see all cancell'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Vsu.
SP.L: 'Tis no past two, and I can stay till three,
Ile make that now my businesse, otherwayes,
With these lowd clamors, I will haunt thee still;
Give me my Vse, giue me my Principall.

SP.SPEAKER: Reig.
SP.L: This burre will still cleaue to me; what, no meanes
To shake him off; I neere was caught till now.
Come come, y'are trouble .

SP.SPEAKER: Vsu.
SP.L: Preuent that trouble,
And without trifling, pay me downe my cash;
I will be fool'd no longer.

SP.SPEAKER: Reig.
SP.L: So so so.

SP.SPEAKER: Vsu.
SP.L: I haue beene still put off, from time to time,
And day to day; these are but cheating tricks,
And this is the last minute ile forbeare
Thee, or thy Master: Once againe, I say,
Giue me my Vse, give me my Principall.

SP.SPEAKER: Reig.
SP.L: Pox a this vse, that hath and one so many:
And now will confound mee.

SP.SPEAKER: Old Lio.
SP.L: Hast thou heard this?

SP.SPEAKER: Ser.
SP.L: Yes Sir, and to my griefe.

SP.SPEAKER: Old Lio.
SP.L: Come hither Reignald.

SP.SPEAKER: Reig.
SP.L: Heere Sir; Nay, now I am gone.

SP.SPEAKER: Old Lio.
SP.L: What vse is this?
What Principall hee talkes of? in which language
Hee names my Sonne; And thus vpbraideth thee,
What is't you owe this man?

SP.SPEAKER: Reig.
SP.L: A trifle Sir,
Pray stop his mouth; And pay't him.

SP.SPEAKER: Old Lio.
SP.L: I pay, what?

SP.SPEAKER: Reig.
SP.L: If I say pay't him; Pay't him.

SP.SPEAKER: Old Lio.
SP.L: What's the Summe?

SP.SPEAKER: Reig.
SP.L: A toy, the maine about fiue hundred pounds;
And the vse fiftie.

SP.SPEAKER: Old Lio.
SP.L: Call you that a toy?
To what vse was it borrowed? At my departure,
I left my Sonne sufficient in his charge,
With surplus, to dey a lage expence,
Without this neede of borrowing.

SP.SPEAKER: Reig.
SP.L: 'Tis confest,
Yet stop his clamorous mouth; And onely say,
That you will pay't to morrow.

SP.SPEAKER: Old Lio.
SP.L: I passe my word.

SP.SPEAKER: Reig.
SP.L: Sir, if I bid you doo't; Nay, no more words,
But say you'le pay't tomorrow.

SP.SPEAKER: Old Lio.
SP.L: Ieast indeed, but tell me how these moneys were bestowed?

SP.SPEAKER: Reig.
SP.L: Safe Sir, I warrant you.

SP.SPEAKER: Old Lio.
SP.L: The Summe still safe,
Why doe you not then tender it your selues?

SP.SPEAKER: Reig.
SP.L: Your eare sir; This summe joyn'd to the rest,
Your Sonne hath purchast Land and Houses.

SP.SPEAKER: Old Lio.
SP.L: Land, do'st thou say?

SP.SPEAKER: Reig.
SP.L: A goodly House, and Gardens.

SP.SPEAKER: Old Lio.
SP.L: Now ioy on him,
That whil'st his Father Merchandis'd abroad,
Had care to adde to his estate at home:
But Reignald, wherefore Houses?

SP.SPEAKER: Reig.
SP.L: Now Lord Sir,
How dull you are; This house possest with spirits,
And there no longer stay; Would you haue had
Him, vs, and all your other family,
To liue, and lie ith' streets; It had not Sir,
Beene for your reputation.

SP.SPEAKER: Old Lio.
SP.L: Blessing on him,
That he is growne so thiftie.

SP.SPEAKER: Vsu.
SP.L: 'Tis strooke three,
My money's not yet tender'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Reig.
SP.L: Pox vpon him,
See him discharged, I pray Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Old Lio.
SP.L: Call vpon me
To morrow Friend, as early as thou wilt;
Ile see thy debt defraid.

SP.SPEAKER: Vsu.
SP.L: It is enough, I haue a true mans word.

SP.SPEAKER: Old Lio.
SP.L: Now tell me Reignald,
For thou hast made me proud of my Sonnes thrift;
Where, in what Countrey, doth this faire House stand.

SP.SPEAKER: Reig.
SP.L: Neuer in all my time, so much to seeke;
I know not what to answere.

SP.SPEAKER: Old Lio.
SP.L: Wherefore studdiest thou?
Vse men to purchase Lands at a deere rate,
And know not where they lie?

SP.SPEAKER: Reig.
SP.L: 'Tis not for that,
I onely had forgot his name that sould them,
'Twas let me see, see.

SP.SPEAKER: Old Lio.
SP.L: Call thy selfe to minde.

SP.SPEAKER: Reig.
SP.L: Non-plust or neuer now; Where art thou braine?
O Sir, where was my memory; 'Tis this house
That next adioynes to yours,

SP.SPEAKER: Old Lio.
SP.L: My Neighbour Ricots.

SP.SPEAKER: Reig.
SP.L: The same, the same Sir; Wee had peniworths in't;
And I can tell you, haue beene offer'd well
Since, to forsake our bargaine.

SP.SPEAKER: Old Lio.
SP.L: As I liue,
I much commend your choice.

SP.SPEAKER: Reig.
SP.L: Nay, 'tis well seated,
Rough-cast without, but brauely lined within;
You haue met with few such bargaines.

SP.SPEAKER: Old Lio.
SP.L: Prethee knocke,
And call the Master, or the seruant on't;
To let me take free view on't.

SP.SPEAKER: Reig.
SP.L: Puzzle againe on Puzzle; One word Sir,
The House is full of Women, no man knowes,
How on the instant, they may be imploy'd;
The Roomes may lie vnhansome; and Maids stand
Much on their cleanlinesse and huswiferie;
To take them vnprouided, were disgrace,
'Twere fit they had some warning; Now, doe you
Fetch but a warrant, from the Iustice Sir;
You vnderstand mee.

SP.SPEAKER: Old Lio.
SP.L: Yes, I doe.

SP.SPEAKER: Reig.
SP.L: To attach him of suspected murder; Ile see't scru'd;
Did he deny't? And in the intrim, I
Will giue them notice, you are now ariu'd,
And long to see your purchase.

SP.SPEAKER: Old Lio.
SP.L: Councell'd well; And meet some halfe houre hence.

SP.SPEAKER: Reig.
SP.L: This plunge well past,
All things fall euen, to Crowne my Braine at last.

SP.SPEAKER: Gent.
SP.L: Where shall we dine to day?

SP.SPEAKER: Dal
SP.L: At th' Ordinarie.
I see Sir, you are but a stranger heere;
This Barnet, is a place of great resort;
And commonly vpon the Market dayes,
Heere all the Countrey Gentlemen Appoint,
A friendly meeting; Some about affaires
