Of Consequence and Profit; Bargaine, Sale,
And to conferre with Chap-men, some for pleasure,
To match their Horses; Wager in their Dogs,
Or trie their Hawkes; Some to no other end,
But onely meet good Company, discourse,
Dine, drinke, and spend their Money.

DIV3.STAGE: Enter Old Geraldine and Yong Geraldine.

SP.SPEAKER: Gent.
SP.L: That's the Market, Wee haue to make this day.

SP.SPEAKER: Dal.
SP.L: 'Tis a Commoditie, that will be easily vented:
What my worthy Friend,
You are happily encounter'd; Oh, y'are growne strange,
To one that much respects you; Troath the House
Hath all this time seem'd naked without you;
The good Old Man doth neuer sit to meat,
But next his giuing Thankes, hee speakes of you;
There's scarce a bit, that he at Table tastes,
That can digest without a Geraldine,
You are in his mouth so frequent: Hee and Shee
Both wondering, what distaste from one, or either,
So suddenly, should alianate a Guest,
To them, so deerely welcome.

SP.SPEAKER: Old Ger.
SP.L: Master Dalauill,
Thus much let me for him Apoligie;
Diuers designes haue throng'd vpon vs late,
My weakenesse was not able to support
Without his helpe; He hath bin much abroad,
At London, or else where; Besides 'tis Terme;
And Lawyers must be followed, seldome at home,
And scarcely then at leasure.

SP.SPEAKER: Dal.
SP.L: I am satisfied,
And I would they were so too, but I hope Sir,
In this restraint, you haue not vs'd my name

SP.SPEAKER: Old Ger.
SP.L: Not, as I liue.

SP.SPEAKER: Dal.
SP.L: Y'are Noble—Who had thought
To haue met with such good Company; Y'are it seeme
But new alighted; Father and Sonne, ere part,
I vow weele drinke a cup of Sacke together:
Phisicians say, It doth prepare the appetite
And stomacke against dinner.

SP.SPEAKER: Old Ger.
SP.L: Wee old men,
Are apt to take these courtesies.

SP.SPEAKER: Dal.
SP.L: What say you Friend?

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Ger.
SP.L: lie but enquire for one, at the next Inne,
And instantly returne.

SP.SPEAKER: Dal.
SP.L: 'Tis enough.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Ger.
SP.L: Besse: How do'st thou Gitle?

SP.SPEAKER: Bess.
SP.P: Faith we may doe how we list for you, you are growne so Great a stranger: We are more beholding
SP.L: To Master Dalauill, Hee's a constant Guest:
And howsoee to some, that shall bee namelesse,
His presence may be gracefull; Yet to others—
I could say somewhat.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Ger.
SP.L: Hee's a noble fellow,
And my choice friend.

SP.SPEAKER: Bess.
SP.L: Come come, he is, what he is; and that the end will prooue.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Ger.
SP.L: And how's all at home?
Nay, weele not part without a glasse of wine,
And meet so seldome: Boy,
Drawer Anon, anon Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Ger.
SP.L: A Pint of Clarret, quickly.
Nay, sit downe: The newes, the newes, I pray thee;
I am sure, I haue beene much enquir'd of
Thy old Master, and thy young Mistris too.

SP.SPEAKER: Bess.
SP.P: Euer your name is in my Masters mouth, and sometimes too In hers, when she hath nothing else to thinke of:
SP.L: Well well, I could say somewhat.

SP.SPEAKER: Drawer
SP.L: Heerc's your wine Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Ger.
SP.P: Fill Boy: Here Besse, this glasse to both their healths; Why do'st weepe my wench?

SP.SPEAKER: Bess.
SP.L: Nay, nothing Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Ger.
SP.L: Come, I must know.

SP.SPEAKER: Bess.
SP.L: Introath I loue you Sir,
And euer wisht you well; You are a Gentleman,
Whom alwayes I respected; Know the passages
And priuate whisperings, of the secret loue
Betwixt you and my Mistris; I dare sweare,
On your part well intended: But—

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Ger.
SP.L: But what?

SP.SPEAKER: Bess.
SP.L: You beare the name of Land-lord, but another
Inioyes the rent; You doate vpon the shadow,
But another he beares away the substance.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Ger.
SP.L: Bee more plaine.

SP.SPEAKER: Bess.
SP.L: You hope to inioy a vertuous widdow-hood;
But Dalauill, whom you esteeme you friend,
Hee keepes the wife in common.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Ger.
SP.L: Y' are too blame,
And Besse, you make me angry; Hee's my friend,
And she my second selfe; In all their meetings,
I neuer saw so much as cast of eye
Once entertain'd betwixt them.

SP.SPEAKER: Bess.
SP.L: That's their cunning.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Ger.
SP.L: For her; I haue beene with her at all houres,
Both late and early; In her bed-chamber.
And often singly vsher'd her abroad:
Now, would she haue bin any mans aliue,
Shee had bin mine; You wrong a worthy Friend,
And a chaste Mistris, y'are not a good Girle;
Drinke that speake better of her, I could chide you,
But I'le forbeare; What you haue rashly spoke,
Shall euer heere be buried.

SP.SPEAKER: Bess.
SP.L: I am sorry my freenesse should offend you,
But yet know, I am her Chamber-maid.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Ger.
SP.L: Play now the Market-maid.
And prethee bout thy businesse.

SP.SPEAKER: Bess.
SP.L: Well, I shall—that man should be so fool'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Ger.
SP.L: Shee a Prostitute?
Nay, and to him my troath plight, and my Friend;
As possible it is, that Heauen and Earth
Should be in love together, meet and kisse,
And so cut off all distance: What strange frensie
Came in this wenches braine, so to surmise?
Were she so base? his noblenesse is such,
He would not entertaine it for my sake:
Or he so bent? His hot and lust burnt appetite
Would be soone quencht, at the meere contemplation
Of her most Pious and Religious life.
The Girle was much too blame; Perhaps her Mistris
Hath stirr'd her anger, by some word or blow,
Which she would thus reuenge; Not apprehending
At what a high price Honour's to be rated;
Or else some one that enuies her rare vertue,
Might hire her thus to brand it; Or, who knowes
But the yong wench may fixe a thought on me;
And to diuert me from her Mistris loue,
May raise this false aspersion? howsoeuer,
My thoughts on these two columnes fixed are,
She's good as fresh, and purely chaste as faire.

SP.SPEAKER: Clo.
SP.P: Oh Sir, you are the Needle, and if the whole County of Mid∣dlesex had bin turn'd to a meere Bottle of Hay, I had bin inioyn'd to haue found you out, or neuer more return'd backe to my old Master: There's a Letter Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Ger.
SP.L: I know the hand that superscrib'd it well;
Stay but till I peruse it, and from me
Thou shalt returne an answere.

SP.SPEAKER: Clo.
SP.P: I shall Sir: This is Market-day, and heere acquaintance com∣monly meet; and whom haue I encounter'd my gossip Pint-pot, and brim full; nay, I meane to drinke with you before I part, and how doth all your worshipfull kindred? your sister Quart, your pater-Pottle, (who was euer a Gentlemans fellow) and your old grandsier Gallon; they cannot chuse but be all in health, since so many healthes haue beene drunke out of them: I could wish them all heere, and in no worse state then I see you are in at this present; howsoeuer gossip, since I haue met you hand to hand, I'le make bould to drinke to you—Nay, either you must pledge me, or get one to doo't for you; Doe you open your mouth towards me? well, I know what you would say; Heere Roger, to your Master and Mistris, and all our good friends at home; gramercy gossip, if I should not pledge thee, I were worthy to be turn'd out to Grasse, and stand no more at Liuery: And now in requitall of this courtesie I'le begin one health to you and all your society in the Oeller, to Peter Pipe, Harry Hogshead, Bartholo∣mew Butt, and little master Randall Rundlet, to Timothy Taster, and all your other great and small friends.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Ger.
SP.L: Hee writes mee heete,
That at my discontinuance hee's much grieu'd,
Desiring me, as I haue cuer render'd
Or him or his, to giue him satisfaction
Touching my discontent; and that in person,
By any priuate meeting.

SP.SPEAKER: Clo.
SP.L: I Sir, 'tis very true, The Letter Speakes no more
Then he wisht me to tell you by word of mouth.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Ger.
SP.L: Thou art then of his councell?

SP.SPEAKER: Clo.
SP.L: His Priuy and please you.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Ger.
SP.L: Though neere so strict hath bin my fathers charge,
A little I'le dispense with't, for his loue;
Commend me to thy Master, tell him from me,
On Munday night (then will my leasure serue)
I will by Heauens assistance visit him.

SP.SPEAKER: Clo.
SP.L: On Munday Sir:
That's as I remember, iust the day before Tuesday.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Ger.
SP.L: But 't will be midnight first, at which late houre,
Please him to let the Garden doore stand ope,
At that I'le enter; But conditionally,
That neither Wife, Friend, Seruant, no third soule
Saue him, and thee to whom he trusts this message,
Know of my comming in, or passing out:
When, tell him, I will fully satisfie him
Concerning my forct absence.

SP.SPEAKER: Clo.
SP.P: I am something obliuious; Your message would bee the true∣lier deliuered if it were set downe in blacke and white.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Ger.
SP.L: I'le call for Pen and Incke,
And instantly dispatch it.

DIV3.HEAD: Scena Prima.

SP.SPEAKER: Reig.
SP.L: Now impudence, but steele my face this once,
Although I neere blush after; Heere's the house,
Ho, whose within? What, no man to desend
These innocent gates from knocking?

SP.SPEAKER: Ric.
SP.L: Whose without there?

SP.SPEAKER: Reig.
SP.L: One Sir that euer wisht your worships health;
And those few houres I can find time to pray in,
I still remember it.

SP.SPEAKER: Ric.
SP.L: Gramercy Reignald,
I loue all those that wish it: You are the men
Leade merry liues, Feast, Reuell, and Carowse;
You seele no tedious houres; Time playes with you,
This is your golden age.

SP.SPEAKER: Reig.
SP.L: It was, but now Sir,
That Gold is turned to worse then Alcamy,
It will not stand the test; Those dayes are past,
And now our nights come on.

SP.SPEAKER: Ric.
SP.L: Tell me Reignald, is he return'd from Sea?

SP.SPEAKER: Reig.
SP.L: Yes, to our griefe already, but we feare
Hereafter, it may prooue to all our cost's.

SP.SPEAKER: Ric.
SP.L: Suspects thy Master any thing?

SP.SPEAKER: Reig.
SP.L: Not yet Sir;
Now my request is, that your worship being
So neere a Neighbour, therefore most disturb'd,
Would not be first to peach vs.

SP.SPEAKER: Ric.
SP.L: Take my word;
With other Neighbours make what peace you can,
I'le not be your accuser.

SP.SPEAKER: Reig.
SP.L: Worshipfull Sir;
I shall be still your Beads-man; Now the businesse
That I was sent about, the Old Man my Master
Claiming some interest in acquaintance past,
Desires (might it be no way trouble some)
To take free view of all your House within.

SP.SPEAKER: Ric.
SP.L: View of my House? Why 'tis not set to Sale,
Nor bill vpon the doore; Looke well vpon't:
View of my House?

SP.SPEAKER: Reig.
SP.L: Nay, be not angry Sir,
Hee no way doth disable your estate;
As farre to buy, as you are loath to sell;
Some alterations in his own hee'd make.
And hearing yours by worke-men much commended,
Hee would make that his President.

SP.SPEAKER: Ric.
SP.L: What fancies
Should at this age possesse him; Knowing the cost,
That hee should dr of Building.

SP.SPEAKER: Reig.
SP.L: 'Tis suppos'd,
He hath late found a Wife out for his Sonne;
Now Sir, to haue him neere him, and that necrenesse
Too, without trouble, though beneath one roofe,
Yet parted in two Families; Hee would build
And make what's pickt, a persit quadrangle,
Proportioned iust with yours, were you so pleased,
To make it his example.

SP.SPEAKER: Ric.
SP.L: Willingly; I will but order some few things within,
And then attend his comming.

SP.SPEAKER: Reig.
SP.L: Most kind cox-combe,
Great Alexander, and Agathocles,
Caesar, and others, haue bin Fam'd, they say.
And magnified for high Facinerous deeds;
Why claime not I, an equall place with them?
Or rather a presedent: These commanded
Their Subiects, and their seruants; I my Master,
And euery way his equalls, where I please,
Lead by the nose along; They plac'd their burdens
On Horses, Mules, and Camels; I, old Men
Of strength and wit, loade with my knauerie,
Till both their backs and braines ake; Yet poore animalls,
They neere complaine of waight; Oh are you come Sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Old Lio.
SP.L: I made what haste I could.

SP.SPEAKER: Reig.
SP.L: And brought the warrant?

SP.SPEAKER: Old Lio.
SP.L: See heere, I hau't.

SP.SPEAKER: Reig.
SP.L: 'Tis well done, but speake, runs it
Both without Baile and Maineprize?

SP.SPEAKER: Old Lio.
SP.L: Nay, it carries both forme and power.

SP.SPEAKER: Reig.
SP.L: Then I shall warrant him;
I haue bin yonder Sir,

SP.SPEAKER: Old Lio.
SP.L: And what sayes hee?

SP.SPEAKER: Reig.
SP.L: Like one that offers you
Free ingresse, view and regresse, at your pleasure;
As to his worthy Land-lord.

SP.SPEAKER: Old Lio.
SP.L: Was that all?

SP.SPEAKER: Reig.
SP.L: Hee spake to me, that I would speake to you,
To speake vnto your Sonne; And then againe,
To speake to him, that he would speake to you;
You would release his Bargaine.

SP.SPEAKER: Old Lio.
SP.L: By no meanes,
Men must aduise before they part with Land,
Not after to repent it; 'Tis most iust,
That such as hazzard, and disburse their Stockes,
Should take all gaines and profits that accrew,
SP.STAGE: Enter Mr. Ricot againe walking before the gate.
SP.L: As well in Sale of Houses, as in Barter,
And Traficke of all other Merchandize.

SP.SPEAKER: Reig.
SP.L: See in acknowledgement of a Tenants duty,
Hee attends you at the gate; Salute him Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Old Lio.
SP.L: My worthy Friend.

SP.SPEAKER: Ric.
SP.L: Now as I liue, all my best thoughts and wishes
Impart with yours, in your so safe returne;
Your seruant tels me, you haue great desire
To take suruiew of this my house within.

SP.SPEAKER: Old Lio.
SP.L: Bee't Sir, no trouble to you.

SP.SPEAKER: Ric.
SP.L: None, enter bouldly;
With as much freedome, as it were your owne.

SP.SPEAKER: Old Lio.
SP.L: As it were mine; Why Reignald, is it not?

SP.SPEAKER: Reig.
SP.L: Lord Sir, that in extremity of griefe,
You'le adde vnto vexation; See you not
How sad hee's on the suddaine,

SP.SPEAKER: Old Lio.
SP.L: I obserue it.

SP.SPEAKER: Reig.
SP.L: To part with that which he hath kept so long;
Especially his Inheritance: Now as you loue
Goodnesse, and Honesty, torment him not
With the least word of Purchase.

SP.SPEAKER: Old Lio.
SP.L: Councell'd well;
Thou teachest me Humanitie.

SP.SPEAKER: Ric.
SP.L: Will you enter?
Or shall I call a seruant, to conduct you
Through euery Roome and Chamber?

SP.SPEAKER: Old Lio.
SP.L: By no meanes;
I feare wee are too much troublesome of our selues.

SP.SPEAKER: Reig.
SP.L: See what a goodly Gate?

SP.SPEAKER: Old Lio.
SP.L: It likes me well.

SP.SPEAKER: Reig.
SP.L: What braue caru'd poasts; Who knowes but heere,
In time Sir, you may keepe your Shreualtie;
And I be one oth' Seriants.

SP.SPEAKER: Old Lio.
SP.L: They are well Caru'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Ric.
SP.L: And cost me a good price Sir, Take your pleasure,
I haue businesse in the Towne.

SP.SPEAKER: Reig.
SP.L: Poore man, I pittie him;
H'ath not the heart to stay and see you come,
As 'twere, to take Possession; Looke that way Sir,
What goodly faire Baye windowes?

SP.SPEAKER: Old Lio.
SP.L: Wondrous stately.

SP.SPEAKER: Reig.
SP.L: And what a Galleric, How costly Seeled;
What painting round about?

SP.SPEAKER: Old Lio.
SP.L: Euery fresh obiect to good, adds betternesse.

SP.SPEAKER: Reig.
SP.L: Tarrast aboue, and how below supported; doe they please you?

SP.SPEAKER: Old Lio.
SP.L: All things beyond opinion; Trust me Reignald,
I'le not forgoe the Bargaine, for more gaine
Then halfe the price it cost me.

SP.SPEAKER: Reig.
SP.L: If you would? I should not suffer you; Was not the
Money due to the Vsurer, tooke vpon good ground,
That prou'd well built vpon? Wee were no fooles
That knew not what wee did.

SP.SPEAKER: Old Lio.
SP.L: It shall be satisfied.

SP.SPEAKER: Reig.
SP.L: Please you to trust me with't, I'le see't discharged.

SP.SPEAKER: Old Lio.
SP.L: Hee hath my promise, and I'le doo't my selfe:
Neuer could Sonne haue better pleas'd a Father,
Then in this Purchase: Hie thee instantly
Vnto my house ith' Countrey, giue him notice
Of my arriue, and bid him with all speede
Poaste hither.

SP.SPEAKER: Reig.
SP.L: Ere I see the warrant seru'd?

SP.SPEAKER: Old Lio.
SP.L: It shall be thy first businesse; For my Soule
Is not at peace, till face to face, I approoue
His Husbandrie, and much commend his Thrift;
Nay, without pause, be gone.

SP.SPEAKER: Reig.
SP.L: But a short iourney;
For hee's not farre, that I am sent to seeke:
I haue got the start, the best part of the Race
is runne already, what remaines, is small,
And tyre now, I should but forfeit all.

SP.SPEAKER: Old Lio.
SP.L: Make haste, I doe intreat thee.

SP.SPEAKER: Clo.
SP.P: This is the Garden gate; And heere am I set to stand Centinell, and to attend the comming of Young Master Geraldine: Master Da∣lauill's gone to his Chamber; My Mistresse to hers; 'Tis now about Mid-night; A Banquet prepared, bottles of Wine in readinesse, all the whole Houshold at their rest; And no creature by this, honestly stir∣ring, sauing I and my Old Master; Hee in a bye Chamber, prepared of purpose for their priuate Meeting; And I heere to play the Watch| Enter Young Geraldine. man, against my will; Chauelah, Stand; Who goes there?

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Ger.
SP.P: A Friend.

SP.SPEAKER: Clo.
SP.P: The Word?

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Ger.
SP.P: Honest Roger.

SP.SPEAKER: Clo.
SP.P: That's the Word indeed; You haue leae to passe freely Without calling my Corporall.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Ger.
SP.P: How goe the affaires within?

SP.SPEAKER: Clo.
SP.P: According to promise, the businesse is composed, and the ser∣ants disposed, my young Mistris reposed, my old Master according as you proposed, attends you if you bee exposed to giue him meeting; Nothing in the way being interposed, to transpose you to the least danger: And this I dare be deposed, if you will not take my word, as I am honest Roger.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Ger.
SP.L: Thy word shall be my warrant, but secur'd
Most in thy Masters promise, on which building;
By this knowne way I enter.

SP.SPEAKER: Clo.
SP.L: Nay, by your leaue, I that was late but a plaine Centinell,
Will now be your Captaine conducter: Follow me.

DIV3.STAGE: Table and Stooles set out; Lights: a Banquet, Wine. Enter Master Wincott.

SP.SPEAKER: Winc.
SP.L: I wonder whence this strangenesse should proceed,
Or wherein I, or any of my house,
Should be th' occasion of the least distaste;
Now, as I wish him well, it troubles me;
But now the time growes on, from his owne mouth
To be resolu'd; And I hope satisfied:
Sir, as I liue, of all my friends to me
Most wishedly, you are welcome: Take that Chaire,
I this: Nay, I inteat no complement;
Attend—Fill wine.

SP.SPEAKER: Clo.
SP.P: Till the mouthes of the bottles yawn directly vpon the floore, and the bottomes turne their rayls vp to the seeling; Whil'st there's any blood in their bellies, I'le not leaue them.

SP.SPEAKER: Winc.
SP.L: I first salute you thus.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Ger.
SP.L: It could not come
From one whom I more honour; Sir, I thanke you.

SP.SPEAKER: Clo.
SP.L: Nay, since my Master begun it, I'le see't goe round
To all three.

SP.SPEAKER: Winc.
SP.L: Now giue vs leaue.

SP.SPEAKER: Clo.
SP.P: Talke you by your selues, whilest I find something to say to this: I haue a tale no tell him shall make his stony heart relent.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Ger.
SP.L: Now, first Sir your attention I intreat;
Next, your beliefe that what I speake is iust,
Maugre all contradiction.

SP.SPEAKER: Winc.
SP.L: Both are granted.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Ger.
SP.L: Then I ; With due acknowledgement
Of all your more then many curtesies:
Y'aue bin my second father, and your wife,
My noble and chaste Mistris; All your seruanes
At my command; And this your bounteous Table,
As free and common as my Fathers house;
Neither 'gainst any, or the least of these,
Can I commence iust quarrell.

SP.SPEAKER: Winc.
SP.L: What might then be
The cause of this constraint, in thus absenting
Your selfe from such as loue you?

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Ger.
SP.L: Out of many,
I will propose some few: The care I haue
Of your (as yet unblemisht) renowne;
The vntoucht honour of your vertuous wife;
And (which I value least, yet dearely too)
My owne faire reputation.

SP.SPEAKER: Winc.
SP.L: How can these, in any way be questioned?

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Ger.
SP.L: Oh deare Sir,
Bad tongues haue bin too busie with vs all;
Of which I neuer yet had time to thinke,
But with sad thoughts and griefes vnspeakeable:
It hath bin whisper'd by some wicked ones,
But loudly thunder'd in my fathers eares,
By some that haue malign'd our happinesse;
(Heaunen, if it can brooke slander, pardon them)
That this my customary comming hither,
Hath bin to base and sorded purposes:
To wrong your bed; Iniure her chastity;
And be mine owne vndoer: Which, how false?

SP.SPEAKER: Winc.
SP.L: As Heauen is true, I know't.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Ger.
SP.L: Now this Calumny
Ariuing first vnto my fathers eares,
His easie nature was induc'd to thinke,
That these things might perhaps be possible:
I answer'd him, as I would doe to Heauen:
And cleer'd my selfe in his suspitious thoughts,
As truely, as the high all-knowing Iudge
Shall of these staines acquit me; which are meerely
Aspersions and vntruthes: The good old man
Possest with my sincerity, and yet carefull
Of your renowne, her honour, and my fame;
To stop the-worst that scandall could inflict;
And to preuent false rumours charges me,
The cause remoou'd, to take away the effect;
Which onely could be, to forbeare your house;
And this vpon his blessing: You heare all.

SP.SPEAKER: Winc.
SP.L: And I of all acquit you: This your absence,
With which my loue most caucll'd; Orators
In your behalfe. Had such things past betwixt you,
Not threats nor chidings could haue driuen you hence:
It pleads in your behalfe, and speakes in hers;
And armes me with a double confidence,
Both of your friendship, and her loyalty:
I am happy in you both, and onely doubtfull
Which of you two doth most impart my loue:
You shall not hence to night.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Ger.
SP.L: Pray pardon Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Winc.
SP.L: You are in your lodging.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Ger.
SP.L: But my fathers charge.

SP.SPEAKER: Winc.
SP.L: My coniuration shall dispence with that;
You may be vp as early as you please;
But hence to night you shall not.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Ger.
SP.L: You are powerfull.

SP.SPEAKER: Winc.
SP.L: This night, of purpose, I haue parted beds,
Faining my selfe not well, to giue you meeting;
Nor can be ought suspected by my Wife,
I haue kept all so priuate: Now 'tis late,
I'le steale vp to my rest, But howsoeuer,
Let's not be strange in our writing, that way dayly
We may conferre without the least suspect,
In spight of all such base calumnious tongues;
So, Now good-night sweet friend

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Ger.
SP.L: May he that made you
So iust and good, still guard you. Not to bed,
So I perhaps might ouer-sleepe my selfe,
And then my tardy wakeing might beay me
To the more early houshold; Thus as I am,
I'le rest me on this Pallar; But in vaine,
I finde no sleepe can fasten on mine eyes,
There are in this disturbed braine of mine
So many mutinous fancies: This, to me,
Will be a tedious night; How shall I spend it?
No Booke that I can spie? no company?
A little let me recollect my selfe;
Oh, what more wisht company can I find,
Suiting the apt occasion, time and place;
Then the sweet contemplation of her Beauty;
And the fruition too, time may produce,
Of what is yet lent out? 'Tis a sweet Lady,
And euery way accomplisht: Hath meere accident
Brought me thus neere, and I not visit her?
Should it ariue here are, perhaps might breed
Our lasting separation; For 'twixt Louers,
No quarrell's to vnkindnesse; Sweet opportunity
Offers preuention, and inuites me too't:
The house is knowne to me, the staires and roomes;
The way unto her chamber frequently
Trodden by me at mid-night, and all houres:
How ioyfull to her would a meeting be,
So strange and unexpected; Shadowed too
Beneath the vaile of night; I am resolu'd
To giue her visitation, in that place
Where we haue past deepe vowes, her bed-chamber:
My fiery loue this darkenesse makes seeme bright,
And and this the path that leades to my delight.
SP.STAGE: He goes in at one doore, and comes out at another.
SP.L: And this the gate vntoo't; I'le listen first,
Before too rudely I disturbe her rest:
And gentle breathing; Ha? shee's sure awake,
For in the bed two whisper, and their voyces
Appeare to me vnequall;—One a womans—
And hers;—Th' other should be no maids tongue,
It beares too big a tone; And harke, they laugh;
(Damnation) But list further; 'Tother sounds—
Like—'Tis the same false periur'd traitor, Dalauill,
To friend and goodnesse: Vnchast impious woman,
False to all faith, and true coniugall loue;
There's met, a Serpent and a Crockadell;
A Synon and a Circe: Oh, to what
May I Compare you?—But my Sword,
I'le act a nobel execution,
On two unmatcht for sorded vilianie:—
I left it in my Chamber, And thankes
That I did to; It hath preuented me
From playing a base Hang-man: Since securely
Whilst I, although for many, yet lesse faults,
Striue hourely to repent me; I once loued her,
And was to him intir'd; Although I pardon,
Heauen will find time to punish, I'le not stretch
My iust reuenge so farre, as once by
To make your brazen Impudence to ;
Damne on, reuenge too great; And to suppresse
Your Soules yet lower, without hope to
Heape Ossa vpon Pelion: You haue made mee
To hate my very Countrey, because heere bred:
Neere two such monsters; First I'le leaue this House,
And then my Fathers; Next I'le take my leaue,
Both of this Clime and Nation, Trauell till
Age snow vpon this Head: My passions now,
Are vnexpressable, I'le end the thus:
Ill man, bad Woman, your vnheard of ,
This uniust censure, on a Iust man giue,
To seeke out place, where no two liue.

DIV3.STAGE: Enter Dalanill as a Night-: Wift in a Night∣tyre, from .

SP.SPEAKER: Dal.
SP.L: A happy Morning now your Lady,
To equall the content of a sweet Night.

SP.SPEAKER: Wife.
SP.L: It hath bin to my wish, your desire:
And this your comming by
Vnto my Sister Pru. cuts of suspition
Of any such conuerse 'twi you and .

SP.SPEAKER: Dal.
SP.L: It hath bin wisely carried.

SP.SPEAKER: Wife.
SP.L: One thing troubles me.

SP.SPEAKER: Dal.
SP.L: What's that my Dearest?

SP.SPEAKER: Wife.
SP.L: Why your Friend Geraldine,
Should on the sudden absent himselfe?
Has he had thinke you no intelligence.
Of these our priuate meetings.

SP.SPEAKER: Dal.
SP.L: No, on my Soule,
For therein hath my braine yours;
I studdying to engrosse you to my selfe,
Of his continued absence haue bin
Yet hee of your affection no way iealous,
Or of my Friendship—How the plot was cast,
You at our better leasure shall pertake;
The aire growes cold, haue care vnto your health,
Suspitious eyes are ore us, that yet sleepe,
But with the dawne, will open; Sweet you
To your warme Sheets; I now to fill my owne,
That haue this Night bin empty.

SP.SPEAKER: Wife.
SP.L: You aduise well;
Oh might this Kisse dwell euer on thy Lips,
In my remembrance.

SP.SPEAKER: Dal.
SP.L: Doubt it not I pray,
Whilest Day frights Night, and Night pursues the day:
Good morrow.

DIV3.STAGE: Enter Reignald, Y. Lionell, Blanda, Scapha, Riote. and two Gallants, Reig. with a Key in his hand.

SP.SPEAKER: Reig.
SP.L: Now is the Goale deliuerie; Through this backe gate
Shift for your selues, I heere vnprison all.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Lio.
SP.L: But tell me, how shall we dispose our selues?
Wee are as farre to seeke now, as the first;
What is it to repreeue vs for few houres,
And now to suffer, better had it bin
At first, to haue stood the triall, so by this,
Wee might haue past our .

SP.SPEAKER: Bla.
SP.L: Sweet Reignald.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Lio.
SP.L: Honest roge.

SP.SPEAKER: Rio.
SP.L: If now thou failest vs, then we are lost for euer,

SP.SPEAKER: Reig.
SP.L: This same sweete Reignald, and this honest rogue,
Hath bin the Burgesse, vnder whose protection
You all this while haue liu'd, free from Arrests,
But now, the Sessions of my power's broake up,
And you expos'd to Actions, Warrants, Writs;
For all the hellish rabble are broke loose,
Of Seriants, Sheriffes, and Baliffes,

SP.SPEAKER: O.
SP.L: Guard vs Heauen,

SP.SPEAKER: Reig.
SP.L: I tell you as it is; Nay, I my selfe
That haue bin your Protector, now as subiect
To euery varlets Pestle, for you know
How I am engag'd with you—At whose suit sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Omn.
SP.L: Why didst thou Start.

SP.SPEAKER: Reig.
SP.L: I was afraid some Catchpole stood behind ,
To clap me on the Shoulder.

SP.SPEAKER: Rio.
SP.L: No such thing; Yet I protest
Thy feare did fright vs all.

SP.SPEAKER: Reig.
SP.L: I knew your guilty conciences.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Lio.
SP.L: No Braine left?

SP.SPEAKER: Ela.
SP.L: No crotchet for my sake?

SP.SPEAKER: Reig.
SP.L: One kisse then Sweete,
Thus shall my crotchets, and your kisses meete.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Lio.
SP.L: Nay, tell vs what to trust too.

SP.SPEAKER: Reig.
SP.L: Lodge your selues
In the next Tauerne, ther's the Cash that's left,
Goe, health it freely for my good successe;
Nay, Drowne it all, let not a Teaster scape
To be consum'd in rot-gut; I haue begun,
And I will stand the period.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Lio.
SP.L: Brauely spoke.

SP.SPEAKER: Reig.
SP.L: Or perisn in the conflict.

SP.SPEAKER: Rio.
SP.L: Worthy Reignald.

SP.SPEAKER: Reig.
SP.L: Well, if he now come off well, Fox you all;
Goe, call for Wine; For singe of my selfe
I will oppose all danger; But I charge you,
When I shall faint or find my selfe disttest;
If I like braue Orlands, winde my Horne,
Make haste vnto my rescew.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Lio.
SP.L: And die in't.

SP.SPEAKER: Reig.
SP.L: Well hast thou spoke my noble Charlemaine,
With these thy Peeres about thee.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Lio.
SP.L: May good Speede
Attend thee still.

SP.SPEAKER: Reig.
SP.L: The end still crownes the deede.

DIV3.STAGE: Enter Old Lionell, and the first Owner of the House.

SP.SPEAKER: Own.
SP.L: Sir sir, your threats nor warrants, can fright me;
My honestie and innocency's knowne
Alwayes to haue bin vnblemisht; Would you could
As well approue your owne Integrity,
As I shall doubtlesse acquit my selfe
Of this surmised murder.

SP.SPEAKER: Old Lio.
SP.L: Rather Surrender
The price I paid, and take into thy hands
This haunted mansion, or I'le prosecute
My wrongs, euen to the vtmost of the Law,
Which is no lesse then death.

SP.SPEAKER: Own.
SP.L: I'le answere all
Old Lionell, both to thy shame and scorne;
This for thy Menaces.

SP.SPEAKER: Clo.
SP.P: This is the House, but where's the noyse that was wont to be in't? I am sent hither, to deliuer a Noate, to two young Gentlemen that heere keepe Reuell-rout; I remember it, since the last Massacre of Meat that was made in't; But it seemes, That the great Storme that was raised then, is chast now; I haue other Noates to deliuer, one to Master Rycott—and—I shall thinke on them all in order; My Old Master makes a great Feast, for the parting of young Master Ge∣raldine, who is presently vpon his departure for Trauell, and the better to grace it, hath inuited many of his Neighbours and Friends; Where will be Old Master Geraldine—his Sonne, and I cannot tell how many; But this is strange, the Gates shut up at this time a day, belike they are all Drunke and laid to sleepe, if they be, I'le wake them, with a Murraine.

SP.SPEAKER: Old Lio.
SP.L: What desperate fellowe's this, that ignorant
Of his owne danger, thunders at these Gates?

SP.SPEAKER: Clo.
SP.L: Ho, Reignald, Riotous Reignald, Reuelling Reignald.

SP.SPEAKER: Old. Lio.
SP.L: What madnesse doth possesse thee, honest Friend,
To touch that Hammers handle?

SP.SPEAKER: Clo.
SP.L: What madnesse doth possesse thee, honest Friend,
To aske me such a question?

SP.SPEAKER: Old Lio.
SP.L: Nay, stirre not yo?

SP.SPEAKER: Own.
SP.L: Not I; The game begins.

SP.SPEAKER: Old Lio.
SP.L: How doest thou, art thou well?

SP.SPEAKER: Clo.
SP.L: Yes very well, I thanke you, how doe you Sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Old Lio.
SP.L: No alteration; What change about thee?

SP.SPEAKER: Clo.
SP.L: Not so much change about me at this time,
As to change you a Shilling into two Teasters.

SP.SPEAKER: Old Lio.
SP.L: Yet I aduise thee Fellow, for thy good,
Stand further from the Gate.

SP.SPEAKER: Clo.
SP.P: And I aduise thee Friend, for thine owne good, stand not be∣twixt mee and the Gate, but giue me leaue to deliuer my erant; Hoe, Reignald, you mad Rascall.

SP.SPEAKER: Old Lio.
SP.L: In vaine thou thunder'st at these silent Doores,
Where no man dwels to answere, sauing Ghosts,
Furies, and Sprights.

SP.SPEAKER: Clo.
SP.P: Ghosts; Indeed there has bin much walking, in and about the House after Mid-night.

SP.SPEAKER: Old Lio.
SP.P: Strange noyse oft heard.

SP.SPEAKER: Clo.
SP.P: Yes, terrible noise, that none of the neighbours could take any rest for it, I haue heard it my selfe.

SP.SPEAKER: Old Lio.
SP.L: You heare this; Heere's more witnesse.

SP.SPEAKER: Own.
SP.L: Very well Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Old Lio.
SP.L: Which you shall dearely answere—whooping.

SP.SPEAKER: Clo.
SP.L: And hollowing.

SP.SPEAKER: Old. Lio.
SP.L: And shouting.

SP.SPEAKER: Clo.
SP.L: And crying out, till the whole house rung againe.

SP.SPEAKER: Old Lio.
SP.L: Which thou hast heard?

SP.SPEAKER: Clo.
SP.L: Oftner then I haue toes and singers.

SP.SPEAKER: Old Lio.
SP.L: Thou wilt be depos'd of this?

SP.SPEAKER: Clo.
SP.L: I'le be sworne too't, and that's as good.

SP.SPEAKER: Old Lio.
SP.L: Very good still; Yet you are innocent:
Shall I intreat thee friend, to auouch as much
Heere by, to the next Iustice.

SP.SPEAKER: Clo.
SP.L: I'le take my souldiers oath on't.

SP.SPEAKER: Old Lio.
SP.L: A souldiers oath, What's that?

SP.SPEAKER: Clo.
SP.P: My corporall oath; And you know Sir, a Corporall is an office belonging to a souldier.

SP.SPEAKER: Old Lio.
SP.L: Yet you are cleere?
Murder will come to light.

SP.SPEAKER: Own.
SP.L: So will your gullery too.

SP.SPEAKER: Rob.
SP.P: They say my old Master's come home; I'le see if hee will turne me out of doores, as the young man has done: I haue laid rods in pisse for some-body, scape Reignald as hee can, and with more free∣dome then I dust late, I bouldly now dare knocke.

SP.SPEAKER: Old Lio.
SP.L: More mad-men yet; I thinke since my last voyage,
Halfe of the world's turn'd franticke: What do'st meane,
Or long'st thou to be blasted?

SP.SPEAKER: Rob.
SP.L: Oh Sir, you are welcome home; 'Twas time to come
Ere all was gone to hauocke.

SP.SPEAKER: Old Lio.
SP.P: My old seruant? before I shall demand of further busin. Resolue me why thou thunder'st at these doores,
SP.L: Where thou know'st none inhabits?

SP.SPEAKER: Rob.
SP.L: Are they gone Sir?
'Twas well yet they haue left the house behind;
For all the furniture, to a bare bench,
I am sure is spent and wasted.

SP.SPEAKER: Old Lio.
SP.L: Where's my sonne,
That Reignald pasting for him with such speed,
Brings him not from the Countrey?

SP.SPEAKER: Rob.
SP.L: Countrey Sir?
'Tis a thing they know not; Heere they Feast,
Dice, Drinke, and Drab; The company they keepe,
Cheaters and Roaring-Ladds, and these attended
By Bawdes and Queanes: Your sonne hath got a Strumpet,
On whom he spends all that your sparing left,
And heere they keepe court; To whose damn'd abuses,
Reignald giues all encouragement.

SP.SPEAKER: Old Lio.
SP.L: But stay stay;
No liuing soule hath for these sixe moneths space
Heere enter'd, but the house stood desolate.

SP.SPEAKER: Rob.
SP.L: Last weeke I am sure, so late, and th' other day,
Such Reuells were here kept.

SP.SPEAKER: Old Lio.
SP.L: And by my sonne?

SP.SPEAKER: Rob.
SP.L: Yes, and his seruant Reignald.

SP.SPEAKER: Old Lio.
SP.L: And this house at all not haunted?

SP.SPEAKER: Rob.
SP.L: Saue Sir with such Sprights.

SP.SPEAKER: Own.
SP.L: This Murder will come out.

SP.SPEAKER: Old Lio.
SP.L: But see, in happy time heere comes my
Neighbour of whom he bought this mansion; He I am sure
More amply can resolue me: I pray Sir,
What summes of moneys haue you late receiued
Of my young sonne?

SP.SPEAKER: Ric.
SP.L: Of him? None I assure you.

SP.SPEAKER: Old Lio.
SP.L: What of my seruant Reignald?

SP.SPEAKER: Ric.
SP.L: But deuise
What to call lesse then nothing, and that summe
I will confesse receiu'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Old Lio.
SP.L: Pray Sir, be serious;
I doe confesse my selfe indebted to you,
A hundred pound.

SP.SPEAKER: Ric.
SP.P: You may doe well to pay't then, for heere's witnesse Sufficient of your words.

SP.SPEAKER: Old Lio.
SP.P: I speake no more then what I purpose; lust so much I owe you, And ere I sleepe will tender.

SP.SPEAKER: Ric.
SP.L: I shall be as ready to receiue it, and as willing,
As you can bee to pay't.

SP.SPEAKER: Old Lio.
SP.L: But prouided,
You will confesse seuen hundred pounds receiued
Before hand of o?

SP.SPEAKER: Ric.
SP.L: But by your fauour;
Why should I yeeld seuen hundred receiu'd
Of them I neuer dealt with? Why? For what?
What reason? What condition? Where or when
Should such a summe be paid mee?

SP.SPEAKER: Old Lio.
SP.L: Why? For this bargaine: And for what? This house,
Reason? Because you sold it: The conditions? Such
As were agreed betweene you: Where and When?
That onely hath escapt me.

SP.SPEAKER: Ric.
SP.L: Madnesse all.

SP.SPEAKER: Old Lio.
SP.L: Was I not brought to take free view thereof,
As of mine owne possession?

SP.SPEAKER: Ric.
SP.L: I confesse;
Your seruant told me you had found out a wife
Fit for your sonne, and that you meant to build;
Desir'd to take a friendly view of mine,
To make it your example: But for selling,
I tell you Sir, my wants be not so great,
To change my house to Coyne.

SP.SPEAKER: Old Lio.
SP.L: Spare Sir your anger,
And turne it into pity; Neighbours and friends,
I am quite lost, was neuer man so so'd,
And by a wicked seruant; Shame and blushing
Will not permit to tell the manner how,
Lest I be made ridiculous to all:
My feares are to inherit what's yet left;
He hath made my sonne away.

SP.SPEAKER: Rob.
SP.L: That's my feare too.

SP.SPEAKER: Old Lio.
SP.L: Friends, as you would a mn
Depriu'd at once, both of his wealth and sonne;
And in his age, by one I euer tender'd
More like a sonne then seruant: By imagining
My case were yours, haue feeling of my griefes
And helpe to apprehend him;
Furnish me with Cords and Fetters,
I will lay him safe in Prison within Prison.

SP.SPEAKER: Ric.
SP.L: Weele assist you.

SP.SPEAKER: Rob.
SP.L: And I.

SP.SPEAKER: Clo.
SP.L: And all;
But not to doe the least hurt to my old friend Reigd.

SP.SPEAKER: Old Lio.
SP.L: His Leggs will be as nimble as his Braine,
And 'twill be difficult to seaze the slaue,
SP.STAGE: Enter Reignald with a Horne in his pocket: they with∣draw behind the Arras.
SP.L: Yet your endeauours, pray peace, heere hoe comes.

SP.SPEAKER: Reig.
SP.L: My heart mis-giues, for 'tis not possible
But that in all these windings and indents
I shall be found at last: I'le take that course
That men both troubled and affrighted doe,
Heape doubt on doubt, and as combustions rise,
Try if from many I can make my peace,
And worke mine owne atonement.

SP.SPEAKER: Old Lio.
SP.L: Stand you close,
Be not yet seene, but at your best aduantage
Hand him, and bind him fast: Whil'st I dissemble
As if I yet knew nothing.

SP.SPEAKER: Reig.
SP.L: I suspect
And find there's trouble in my Masters lookes;
Therefore I must not trust my selfe too farre
Within his fingers.

SP.SPEAKER: Old Lio.
SP.L: Reignald?

SP.SPEAKER: Reig.
SP.L: Worshipfull Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Old Lio.
SP.L: What sayes my sonne ith' Countrey?

SP.SPEAKER: Reig.
SP.L: That tomorrow,
Early ith' morning, heele attend your pleasure,
And doe as all such dutious children ought;
Demand your blessing Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Old Lio.
SP.L: Well, 'tis well.

SP.SPEAKER: Reig.
SP.L: I doe not like his countenance.

SP.SPEAKER: Old Lio.
SP.L: But Reignald? I suspect the honesty
And the good meaning of my neighbour heere,
Old master Ricott; Meeting him but now,
And hauing some discourse about the house,
He makes all strange, and tells me in plaine termes,
Hee knowes of no such matter.

SP.SPEAKER: Reig.
SP.L: Tell mee that Sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Old Lio.
SP.L: I tell thee as it is:
Nor that such moneys, tooke vp at vse, were euer tender'd him
On any such conditions.

SP.SPEAKER: Reig.
SP.L: I cannot blame your worship to bee pleasant,
Knowing at what an vnder-rate we bought it, but you euer
Were a most merry Gentleman.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Lio.
SP.L: (Impudent )
But Reignald, hee not onely doth demie it,
But offers to depose Himself and Seruants,
No such thing euer was.

SP.SPEAKER: Reig.
SP.L: Now Heauen, to see to what this world's groe too.
I will make him—

SP.SPEAKER: Old Lio.
SP.L: Nay more, this mn will not confesse the Murder.

SP.SPEAKER: Reig.
SP.L: Which both shall deerely answere; You have warrant
For him already; But for the other Sir,
If hee denie it, he had better—

SP.SPEAKER: Old Lio.
SP.L: Appeare Gentlemen,
'Tis a fit time to take him.

SP.SPEAKER: Reig.
SP.L: I discouer the Ambush that's laid for me.

SP.SPEAKER: Old Lio.
SP.L: Come neerer Reignald.

SP.SPEAKER: Reig.
SP.L: First sir resolue me one thing, amongst other Merchandize
Bought in your absence by your Sonne and me,
Wee ingrost a great comoditie of Combes,
And how many sorts thinke you?

SP.SPEAKER: Old Lio.
SP.L: You might buy
Some of the bones of Fishes, some of Beasts,
Box-combes, and Iuery .

SP.SPEAKER: Reig.
SP.L: But besides these, we haue for Horses Si,
Mayne-combes, and Curry-combes; Now Sir for men,
Wee haue Head-oombes, -combes, I and Cox-combes too;
Take view of them at your pleasure, whil'it for my part,
I thus bestow my selfe.

DIV3.STAGE: They all appeare and Shackes, Whilest hee goes vp.

SP.SPEAKER: Clo.
SP.L: Well said Reignald, nobly put off Reignald,
Looke to thy selfe Reignald.

SP.SPEAKER: Old Lio.
SP.L: Why dost thou clibo thus?

SP.SPEAKER: Reig.
SP.L: Onely to practice
The nimblenesse of my Armes and Legges,
Ere they prooue your Cords and Fetters.

SP.SPEAKER: Old Lio.
SP.L: Why to that place?

SP.SPEAKER: Reig.
SP.P: Har∣bour long, and now it must bee my Sanctuary; Dispute now, and I'le answere.

SP.SPEAKER: Own.
SP.L: To challenge me of Murder?

SP.SPEAKER: Reig.
SP.P: Oh sir, the man you kil'd is aliue at this present to iustisie it: I am, quoth he, a Trans-marine by birth—

SP.SPEAKER: Ric.
SP.P: Why, challenge me receipt of Moneys, and to giue abroad, That I had sold my House?

SP.SPEAKER: Reig.
SP.L: Why? because sir,
Could I haue purchast Houses at that rate,
I had meant to haue bought all London.

SP.SPEAKER: Clo.
SP.L: Yes, and Middlesex too, and I would haue bin thy halfe Reig∣nald.

SP.SPEAKER: Old Lio.
SP.L: Yours are great,
My wrongs insufferable; As first, to fright mee
From mine owne dwelling, till they had consumed
The whole remainder of the little left;
Besides, out of my late stocke got at Sea,
Discharge the clamorous Vsurer; Make me accuse
This man of Murder; Be at charge of warrants;
And challenging this my worthy Neighbour of
Forswearing Summes hee neuer yet receiued;
Foole mee, to thinke my Sonne that had spent all,
Had by his thrift bought Land; I and him too,
To open all the secrets of his House
To mee, a Stranger, On thou insolent villaine,
What to all these canst answere?

SP.SPEAKER: Reig.
SP.L: Guiltie, guiltie.

SP.SPEAKER: Old Lio.
SP.L: But to my Sonnes death, what thou slaue?

SP.SPEAKER: Reig.
SP.L: Not Guiltie.

SP.SPEAKER: Old Lio.
SP.L: Produce him then; Ith' meane time, and—
Honest Friends, get Ladders.

SP.SPEAKER: Reig.
SP.L: Yes, and come downe in your owne Ropes.

SP.SPEAKER: Own.
SP.L: I'le fetch a Peece and shoote him.

SP.SPEAKER: Reig.
SP.P: So the warrant in my Masters pocket, will serue for my Mur∣der; And euer after shall my Ghost haunt this House.

SP.SPEAKER: Clo.
SP.L: And I will say like Reignald,
This Ghost and I am Friends.

SP.SPEAKER: Old Lio.
SP.L: Bring faggots, I'le set fire vpon the House,
Rather then this indure.

SP.SPEAKER: Reig.
SP.L: To burne Houses is Fellony, and I'le not out
Till be fir'd out; But since I am Besieged thus,
I'le summon supplies vnto my Rescue.

DIV3.STAGE: Hee windes a Horne. Enter Young Lionell, Rioter, two Gallants Blanda, &c.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Lie.
SP.L: Before you chide, first heere mee, next your Blessing,
That on my knees I begge; I have but done,
Like mis-spent youth, which after wit deere bought,
Turnes his Eyes inward, sorrie and ashamed;
These things in which I haue offended most,
Had I not prooued, I should haue thought them still
Essentiall things, delights perdureable;
Which now I find meere Shaddowes, Toyes and Dreames,
Now hated more then earst I doated on;
Best Natures, are soonest wrought on; Such was mine;
As I the offences, So the offendors throw
Heere at your feete, to punish as you please;
You haue but paid so much as I have wasted,
To purchase to your selfe a thrifty Sonne;
Which I from hencefoorth, Vow.

SP.SPEAKER: Old Lio.
SP.L: See what Fathers are,
That can three yeeres offences, fowle ones too,
Thus in a Minute pardon; And thy faults
Vpon my selfe chastise, in these my Teares;
Ere this Submission, I had cast thee off;
Rise in my new Adoption: But for these—

SP.SPEAKER: Clo.
SP.P: The one you have nothing to doe withall, here's his Ticket for his discharge; Another for you Sir, to Summon you to my Masters Feast, For you, and you, where I charge you all to appeare, vpon his displeasure, and your owne apperils.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Lio.
SP.L: This is my Friends one I loued,
Onely because they haue bin deere to him
That now will striue to be more deere to you;
Vouchsafe their pardon.

SP.SPEAKER: Old Lio.
SP.L: All deere, to me indeed, for I haue payd for't soundly,
Yet for the sake, I am atton'd with all; Onely that wanton.
Her, and her Company, abandon quite;
So doing, wee are friends.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Lie.
SP.L: A iust Condition, and willingly subscrib'd to.

SP.SPEAKER: Old Lio.
SP.L: But for that Villaine; I am now deuising
What shame, what punishment remarkable,
To inflict on him.

SP.SPEAKER: Reig.
SP.L: Why Master? Haue I laboured;
Plotted, Contriued, and all this while for you,
And will you leaue me to the Whip and Stockes;
Not mediate my peace.

SP.SPEAKER: Old Lio.
SP.L: come downe.

SP.SPEAKER: Reig.
SP.L: Not till my Pardon's sealed, I'le rather stand heere
Like a Statue, in the Fore-front of your house
For euer; Like the picture of Dame Fortune
Before the Fortune Play-house.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Lio.
SP.L: If I haue heere
But any Friend amongst you, ioyne with mee
In this petition.

SP.SPEAKER: Clo.
SP.L: Good Sir, for my sake, I resolued you truely
Concerning Whooping, the Noyse, the Walking; and the Sprights,
And for a need, can shew you a Ticket for him too.

SP.SPEAKER: Own.
SP.L: I impute my wrongs rather to knauish Cunning,
Then least pretended Malice.

SP.SPEAKER: Ric.
SP.L: What he did,
Was but for his Young Master, I allow it
Rather as sports of Wit, then iniuries;
No other pray esteeme them.

SP.SPEAKER: Old Lio.
SP.L: Euen as freely,
As you forget my quarells made with you;
Rais'd from the Errours first begot by him;
I heere remit all free; I now am Calme,
But had I seaz'd vpon him in my Spleene—

SP.SPEAKER: Reig.
SP.L: I knew that, therefore this was my Inuention,
For Pollicie's the art still of Preuention.

SP.SPEAKER: Clo.
SP.P: Come downe then Reignald, first on your hands and feete, and then on your knees to your Master; Now gentlemen, what doe you say to your inuiting to my Masters Feast.

SP.SPEAKER: Ric.
SP.L: Wee will attend him.

SP.SPEAKER: Old Lio.
SP.L: Nor doe I loue to breake good company;
For Master Wincott is my worthy Friend,
And old acquaintance; Oh thou crafty Wag-string,
And could'st thou thus delude me? But we are Friends;
Nor Gentlemen, let not what's heere to past,
In your least thoughts disable my Estate;
This my last Voyage hath made all things good,
With surplus too; Be that your comfort Sonne:
Well Reignald—But no more.

SP.SPEAKER: Reig.
SP.L: I was the Fox,
But I from hencefoorth, will no more the Cox—
Combe, put vpon your pate.

SP.SPEAKER: Old Lio.
SP.L: Let's walke Gentlemen

DIV3.HEAD: Scena Prima.
DIV3.STAGE: Enter Old Geraldine, and Young Geraldine.

SP.SPEAKER: Old Ger.
SP.L: Sonne, let me tell you, you are ill aduised;
And doubly to be blam'd, by vndertaking
Vnnecessary trauell; Grounding no reason
For such a rash and giddy enterprise:
What profit aime you at, you haue not reapt;
What Nouelty affords the Christian world,
Of which your view hath not participated
In a full measure; Can you either better
Your language or experience? Your selfe-will
Hath onely purpose to depriue a father
Of a loued sonne, and many noble friends,
Of your much wisht aquaintance.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Ger.
SP.L: Oh, deare Sir,
Doe not, I doe intreat you, repent you
Of your free grant; Which with such care and studdy.
I haue so long, so often laboured for.

SP.SPEAKER: Old Ger.
SP.L: Say that may be dispens'd with, shew me reason
Why you desire to out of your Countrey,
Like some Malefactor that had forfeited
His life and freedome; Heere's a worthy Gentleman
Hath for your sake inuited many guests,
To his great charge, onely to take of you
A parting leaue; You send him word you cannot,
After, you may not come: Had not my vrgence,
Almost compulsion, driuen you to his house,
Th' vnkindnesse might haue forfeited your loue,
And raced you from his will; In which he hath giuen you,
A faire and large estate; Yet you of all this stangenesse,
Show no sufficient ground.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Ger.
SP.L: Then vnderstand;
The ground thereof tooke his first birth from you;
'Twas you first charg'd me to forbeare the house,
And that vpon your blessing: Let it not then
Offend you Sir, if I so great a charge
Haue striu'd to keepe so strictly.

SP.SPEAKER: Old Ger.
SP.L: Mee perhaps,
You may appease, and with small difficulty.
Because a Father; But how satisfie
Their deare, and on your part, vnmerited loue?
But this your last obedience may salue all:
Wee now grow neere the house.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Ger.
SP.L: Whose doores, to mee,
Appeare as horried as the gates of Hell:
Where shall I borrow patience, or from whence?
SP.STAGE: Enter Wincott, Wife, Ricott, the two Lionells, Owner, Dalauill, Prudentilla, Reignald, Rioter.
SP.L: To giue a meeting to this viperous brood,
Of Friend and Mistris.

SP.SPEAKER: Winc.
SP.L: Y'aue entertain'd me with a strange discourse
Of your mans knauish wit, but I reioyce,
That in your safe returne, all ends so well:
Most welcome you, and you, and indeed all;
To whom I am bound, that at so short a warning,
Thus friendly, you will deigne to visit me.

SP.SPEAKER: Old Lio.
SP.L: It seemes my absence hath begot some sport,
Thanke my kind seruant heere.

SP.SPEAKER: Reig.
SP.L: Not so much worth Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Old Lio.
SP.L: But though their riots tript at my estate,
They haue not quite ore-throwne it.

SP.SPEAKER: Winc.
SP.P: But see Gentlemen, these whom we most expected, come at length; This I proclaime the master of the Feast,
SP.L: In which to expresse the bounty of my loue,
I'le shew my selfe no niggard.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Ger.
SP.L: Your choise fauours,
I still taste in abundance.

SP.SPEAKER: Wife
SP.L: Methinks it would not mis-become me Sir,
To chide your absence; That haue made your selfe,
To vs, so long a stranger.

DIV3.STAGE: Hee turnes away sad, as not being minded.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Ger.
SP.L: Pardon mee Sir,
That haue not yet, since your returne from Sea,
Voted the least fit opportunity,
To entertaine you with a kind salute.

SP.SPEAKER: Old Lio.
SP.L: Most kindly Sir I thanke you.

SP.SPEAKER: Dal.
SP.L: Methinks friend,
You should expect greene rushes to be strow'd,
After such discontinuance.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Ger.
SP.L: Mistris Pru,
I haue not seene you long, but greet you thus,
May you be Lady of a better husband
Then I expect a wife.

SP.SPEAKER: Winc.
SP.L: I like that greeting:
Nay, enter Gentlemen; Dinner perhaps
Is not yet ready, but the time we stay,
Weele find some fresh discourse to spend away.

SP.SPEAKER: Dal.
SP.L: Not speake to me? nor once vouchsafe an answere,
But sleight me with a poore and base neglect?
No, nor so much as cast an eye on her,
Or least regard, though in a seeming shew
Shee courted a reply? 'twixt him and her,
Nay him and mee, this was not wont to be;
If she haue braine to apprehend as much
As I haue done, sheele quickly find it out:
Now as I liue, as our affections meete,
So our conceits, and shee hath singled him
To some such purpose: I'le retire my selfe.
Not interrupt their conference.

SP.SPEAKER: Wife.
SP.L: You are sad Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Ger.
SP.L: I know no cause.

SP.SPEAKER: Wife
SP.L: Then can I shew you some;
Who could be otherwayes, to leaue a Father
So carefull, and each way so prouident?
To leaue so many, and such worthy Friends?
To abandon your owne countrey? These are some,
Nor doe I thinke you can be much the merrier
For my sake?

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Ger.
SP.L: Now your tongue speakes Oracles;
For all the rest are nothing, 'tis for you,
Onely for you I cannot.

SP.SPEAKER: Wife
SP.L: So I thought;
Why then haue you bin all this while so strange?
Why will you trauell? suing a diuorce
Betwixt vs, of a loue inseperable;
For heere shall I be left as desolate
Vnto a frozen, almost widdowed bed;
Warm'd onely in that future, stor'd in you;
For who can in your absence comfort me?

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Ger.
SP.L: Shall my oppressed sufferance yet breake foorth
Into impatience, or endure her more?

SP.SPEAKER: Wife
SP.L: But since by no perswasion, no intreats,
Your setled obstinacy can be swal'd,
Though you seeme desperate of your owne deare life
Haue care of mine, for it exists in you.
Oh Sir, should you miscarry I were lost,
Lost and forsaken; Then by our past vowes,
And by this hand once giuen mee, by these reares,
Which are but springs begetting greater floods,
I doe beseech thce, my deere Geraldine,
Looke to thy safety, and preserue thy health;
Haue care into what company you fall;
Trauell not late, and crosse no dangerous Seas;
For till Heauens blesse me in thy safe returne,
How will this poore heart suffer?

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Ger.
SP.L: I had thought
Long since the Syrens had bin all destroy'd;
But one of them I find suruiues in her;
Shee almost makes me question what I know,
An Hereticke vnto my owne beliefe:
Oh thou mankinds seducer.

SP.SPEAKER: Wife
SP.L: What? no answere?

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Ger.
SP.L: Yes, thou hast spoke to me in Showres,
I will reply in Thunder; Thou Adultresse,
That hast more poyson in thee then the Serpent,
Who was the first that did corrupt thy sex,
The Deuill.

SP.SPEAKER: Wife
SP.L: To whom speakes the man?

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Ger.
SP.L: To thee, falsest of all that euer man term'd faire;
Hath Impudence so stool'd thy smooth soft skin,
It cannot blush? Or sinne so obdur'd thy heart,
It doth not quake and tremble? Search thy conscience,
There thou shalt find a thousand clamorous tongues
To speake as loud as mine doth.

SP.SPEAKER: Wife.
SP.L: Saue from yours,
I heare no noise at all.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Ger.
SP.L: I'le play the Doctor
To open thy deafe eares; Munday the Ninth
Of the last Moneth; Canst thou remember that?
That Night more blacke in thy abhorred sinne,
Then in the gloomie darknesse; That the time.

SP.SPEAKER: Wife.
SP.L: Munday?

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Ger.
SP.L: Wouldest thou the place know? Thy polluted Chamber,
So often, witnesse of my sin-lesse vowes;
Wouldest thou the Person? One not worthy Name,
Yet to torment thy guilty Soule the more,
I'le tell him thee, That Monster Dalauill;
Wouldest thou your Bawd know? Mid-night, that the houre;
The very words thou spae? Now what would Geraldine
Say, if he saw vs heere? To which was answered,
Tush hee's a Cox-combe, fit to be so fool'd:
No blush? What, no faint Feauer on thee yet?
How hath thy blacke sins chang'd thee? Thou Medusa,
Those Haires that late appeared li golden Wyers,
Now crawle with Snakes and Adders; Thou art vgly.

SP.SPEAKER: Wife.
SP.L: And yet my glasse, till now, neere told me so;
Who gaue you this intelligence?

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Ger.
SP.L: Onely hee,
That pittying such an Innocentis mine,
Should by two such delinquents bee beray'd,
Hee brought me to that place by mirracle;
And made mean eare witnesse of all this.

SP.SPEAKER: Wife.
SP.L: I am vndone.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Ger.
SP.L: But thinke wharthou hast lost
To forfeit mee; I not withstanding these,
(So fixt was my loue and verable)
I kept this from thy Husband, nay all eares,
With thy transgressions smothering mine owne wrongs,
In hope of thy

SP.SPEAKER: Wife.
SP.L: Which begin thus low vpon my knees.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Ger.
SP.L: Tush, bow in ,
Which thou hast most offended; alas,
Saue in such (Scace vnheard of) Treacherie,
Most sinfull like thy selfe;
Wherein, Oh wherein, hath my vnspotted and vnbounded Loue
deseru'd the least of these? Sworne to be made a ale
For terme of life; And all this for my goodnesse;
Die, and die soone, acquit me of my Oath,
But prethee die repentant; Farewell euer,
'Tis thou, and onely thou hast Banisht mee,
Both from my Frinds and Countrey.

SP.SPEAKER: Wife.
SP.L: Oh, I am lost.

DIV3.STAGE: Enter Dalauill meeting Young Geraldine going out.

SP.SPEAKER: Dal.
SP.L: Why how now, what's the businesse?

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Ger.
SP.P: Goe take her Vp, whom thou hast oft throwne Downe, Villaine.

SP.SPEAKER: Dal.
SP.L: That was no language from a Friend,
It had too harsh an accent; But how's this?
My Mistresse thus low cast vpon the earth
Grauelling and breathlesse, Mistresse, Lady, Sweet—

SP.SPEAKER: Wife.
SP.L: Oh tell me if thy name be Geraldine,
Thy very lookes will kill mee?

SP.SPEAKER: Dal.
SP.L: View me well,
I am no such man; See, I am Dalauill.

SP.SPEAKER: Wife.
SP.L: Th'art then a Deuill, that presents before mee
My horrid sins; perswades me to dispaire;
When hee like a good Angel sent from Heauen,
Besought me of repentance; Swell sicke Heart,
Euen till thou burst the ribs that bound thee in;
So, there's one string crackt, flow, and flow high,
Euen till thy blood distill out of mine eyes,
To witnesse my great sorrow.

SP.SPEAKER: Dal.
SP.L: Faint againe,
Some helpe within there, no attendant neere?
Thus to expire, in this I am more wretched,
Then all the sweet fruition of her loue
Before could make me happy.

DIV3.STAGE: Enter Wincott Old Geraldine, Young Geraldine, the two Lionells, Ricott, Owner, Prudentilla, Reignald, Clowne.

SP.SPEAKER: Winc.
SP.L: What was hee clamor'd so lowd,
To mingle with our mirth this terrour
And affright?

SP.SPEAKER: Dal.
SP.L: See Sir, your Wife in these my armes expiring.

SP.SPEAKER: Winc.
SP.L: How?

SP.SPEAKER: Prud.
SP.L: My sister?

SP.SPEAKER: Winc.
SP.L: Support her, and by all meanes possible
Prouide for her deere safety.

SP.SPEAKER: Old Ger.
SP.L: See, shee recouers.

SP.SPEAKER: Winc.
SP.L: Woman, looke vp.

SP.SPEAKER: Wife.
SP.L: Oh Sir, your pardon;
Conuey me to my Chamber, I am sicke,
Sicke euen to death, away thou Sycophant,
Out of my sight, I haue besides thy selfe,
Too many sinnes about mee.

SP.SPEAKER: Clo.
SP.L: My sweet Mistresse.

SP.SPEAKER: Dal.
SP.L: The storme's comming, I must prouide for harbour.

SP.SPEAKER: Old Lio.
SP.L: What strange and sudden alteration's this,
How quickly is this cleere day ouercast,
But such and so vncertaine are all things,
That dwell beneath the Moone.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Lio.
SP.L: A Womans qualme,
Frailties that are inherent to her sex,
Soone sicke, and soone recouer'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Winc.
SP.L: If shee misfare,
I am a man more wretched in her losse,
Then had I forfeited life and estate;
Shee was so good a creature.

SP.SPEAKER: Old Ger.
SP.L: I the like
Suffer'd, when I my Wife brought vnto her grae;
So you, when you were first a widower,
Come arme your selfe with patience.

SP.SPEAKER: Ric.
SP.L: These are casualties
That are not new, but common.

SP.SPEAKER: Reig.
SP.L: Burying of Wiues,
As stale as shifting shifts, or for some seruants,
To flout and gull their Masters.

SP.SPEAKER: Own.
SP.L: Best to send
And see how her fit holds her.

SP.SPEAKER: Prud.
SP.L: Sir, my
In these few Lines commends her last to you,
For she is now no more; What's therein writ,
Saue Heauen and you, none knowes, This she desir'd
You would take view of; and with these words expired.

SP.SPEAKER: Winc.
SP.L: Dead?

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Ger.
SP.L: She hath made one then a free release,
Of all the debts I owed her.

SP.SPEAKER: Winc.
SP.L: My feare is beyond pardon, Dalauill
Hath plaid the villaine, but for Geraldine,
Hee hath bin each way Noble—Loue him still,
My peace already I haue made with Heauen;
Oh be not you at warre with me; My Honour
Is in your hands to punish, or preserue;
I am now Confest, and only Geraldine
Hath wrought on mee this vnexpected good;
The Inke I write with, I wish had bin my blood,
To witnesse me Repentance—Dalauill?
Where's hee? Goe seeke him out.

SP.SPEAKER: Clo.
SP.L: I shall, I shall Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Winc.
SP.L: The Wills of Dead folke should be still obeyed;
How euer false to mee, I'le not reueale't;
Where Heauen forgiues, I pardon Gentlemen,
I know you all commiserate my losse;
I little thought this Feast should haue bin turn'd
Into a Funerall; What's the newes of him?

SP.SPEAKER: Clo.
SP.P: Hee went presently to the Stable, put the Sadle vpon his Horse, put his Foote into the Stirrup, clapt his Spurres into his sides, and a∣way hee's Gallopt, as if hee were to ride a Race for a Wager.

SP.SPEAKER: Winc.
SP.L: All our ill lucks goe with him, farewell hee;
But all my best of wishes wait on you,
As my chiefe Friend; This meeting that was made
Onely to take of you a parting leaue,
Shall now be made a Marriage of our Loue,
Which none saue onely Death shall separate.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Ger.
SP.L: It calles me from all Trauell, and from hencefoorth,
With my Countrey I am Friends.

SP.SPEAKER: Winc.
SP.L: The Lands that I haue left,
You lend mee for the short space of my life;
As soone as Heauen calles mee, they call you Lord;
First feast, and after Mourne; Wee'le like some Gallants
That Bury thrifty Fathers, think't no sinne,
To weare Blacks without, but other Thoughts within.
